column10: This course explores key themes of philosophy, such as the nature of existence, analysis of language and cognition, and social and ecological ethics, in traditions such as Buddhism, Hinduism, Jainism, Daoism, and Confucianism. Emphasis is placed on how philosophy changes over time and is applied to diverse real-world agendas.

column9: "This course introduces the cross-disciplinary study of this global phenomenon [that more than half the world's population live in the countries of the Asia-Pacific region], exploring the heightened importance of human mobility in the age of 'Asian Century.' Transregional and transnational flows of people, goods, capital, and ideas within and beyond the Asia-Pacific will be examined in order to trace their global and local implications, which often result in the transformation of cultural identities, gendre relations, trade networks, and poltiical mobilizations". One of the learning outcomes is to "appreciate the broader significance of studying human mobility in the rapidly changing world"
column10: This course introduces students to the cross-disciplinary study of human mobility in the Asia-Pacific. Intra-Asia flows of people will be examined in order to trace their multifaceted implications. On completing the course, students should be able to present their own thinking on complex issues related to global migration.

column9: Not convinced after reading syllabus - more ethnographic and investigative than problem-solving, and the topics it is investigating are related to culture and society rather than contemporary challenges
column10: This course offers comprehensive training to students interested in learning about ethnographic research, analysis, and writing in/of the contemporary Asia in a global context, with a special focus on Houston. Seminar-style discussion on ethnographic research methods and hands-on field research on several Asian-American communities will comprise the major course activities.

column9: "This course examines the diversity and complexity of Muslim women’s lives and faith around the world. It explores changing constructions of gender and sexuality in the Islamic world over time; the interactions between Muslims and travelers, colonial administrators, the modern state, and local and transnational feminist, secularist, and Islamist movements; and, generally, continuing challenges to the very notion of what it means to be Muslim." - focus on gender, sexuality, and Islam (religion/religious inequities/differences) - but religious difference is not a notable sustainability challenge
column10: Explores the lives of Muslim women in Asia, the Middle East, Europe, and North America; analyzes constructions of gender in the Islamic world overtime; the challenges faced from such diverse quarters as colonial administrators, Western feminists, and states; as well as movements and individuals within the Muslim world.

column9: Not convinced after syllabus - more of an introductory review course
column10: Buddhist ideas, art, and meditation. Exploration of the Buddhism in India, China, and Japan and their impact in the USA today. Readings include Buddhists classics and contemporary responses from mediators and scientists.

column5: Buddhist And Daoist Art In China
column9: Not convinced after syllabus - more of an introductory course. although it focuses on specific themes each week, none are specific to sustainability
column10: This course explores the visual materials that shed light on pre-modern China’s Buddhist, Daoist, and other diverse religious and ritual practices. We will examine the range of social and ethnic backgrounds that participated in the making, spreading, and use of religious visual culture in traditional China. Topics may include: funeral art and ritual; images of heaven, hell, and rebirth; and representations of gender, among others. Students will develop analytical skills, critical thinking skills, and holistic views regarding the meaning, function, and style of the arts of diverse religious traditions in China.

column5: Modern Girl And Asia In The World
column9: Forward-looking, focused on modernity and consumer culture alongside sexuality
column10: Using the textbook "The Modern Girl Around the World," this course examines the phenomenon of the so-called modern girl in Asia and the world, 1890-1949. Topics include: modernity, consumer culture, sexuality, and liberation.

column9: "Topics include: China’s modernity and the formation and cinematic visualization of modern Chinese literature; self, state, and nation; sex, gender, and power; connections between China’s past and present, etc." - the course will help students "overcome their originally orientalist, occidentalist, or any kind of chauvinistic and centralist perspectives, in order for them to view the world from a humanitarian position, especially on behalf of marginalized groups of people and beings." - this frame shifting feels important based on the sustainbility challenges.
column10: Exploration of modern Chinese literature through the visual imagery of Chinese films to show how and why different time periods and different media affect the theme of a story. One third covers movie adaptations of classical Chinese literature. Films subtitled in English, shown outside of class. All readings in English translation.

column9: Not convinced after reading syllabus - less "zoomed out" and more focused on the content of the Tales
column10: Learning Chinese literature and culture through reading vernacular stories, fantastic tales, biographies, and philosophical parables. Discussion topics: literature and Confucianism, Taoism and Buddhism; literature and history; self and other; fantastic world and reality; women as domestic aliens and aliens portrayed as women, etc. Readings are in English translation.

column9: Contains a similar note in learning objectives to ASIA 332. "The course will also help them overcome their originally orientalist, occidental, or any kind of centralist perspectives, in order for them to view the world from a humanitarian position, especially on behalf of marginalized groups of peoples and beings." But this is more classical and historical in nature rather than contemporary or forward looking
column10: Examination of the basic characteristics of classical Chinese novels, primarily through six important works from the 16th to 18th centuries: Water Margin, Monkey, Golden Lotus, Scholars, Romance of the Three Kingdoms, and Dream of the Red Chamber. All readings in English translation.

column5: Geographies Of Religion In South Asia
column9: "Topics range from early archaeological records and textual accounts of pilgrimage to historical transformations, contemporary reconfigurations, and appropriatons of objects and spaces." - not quite focused enough
column10: This course examines fundamental concepts of South Asian religious geography in a variety of historical periods and from diverse theoretical approaches. Using early texts, contemporary ethnographies, and numerous objects of visual and material culture, we explore diverse religious experiences of landscape in Buddhism, Hinduism, and Jainism.

column9: No notable focus on sustainability in description
column10: This course examines the dynamics of urban politics and policy in an emerging global city - Istanbul. In addition to social, political and economic issues, we will also focus on history, culture, language, architecture and the arts. Weekly class sessions will include lectures, case studies, guest lecturers, and group work on research projects. The lab also features an 8-day field research trip to Istanbul.

column9: Not oriented towards sustainability specificially
column10: This course examines the functioning of the political system in the three principal East Asian democracies: Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan. Particular focus is paid to each country's democratic institutions, electoral politics, and political party system.

column9: "this class will examine the relationship between film and urban space... includ[ing] parallels between cinematic and urban space... and the intertwined histories of film and urban design"  - thinking about urbanism and industrialization - but the stdy of urban spaces does not always imply the study of sustainability
column10: This class explores representations of the city in 20th and 21st century world cinema. Central concerns will include the city as cinematic protagonist, parallels between urban and cinematic space and the intertwined histories of both film and urban design over the last century.

column9: "We will examine how science and technology is both shaped by and influences social differences such as race, caste, ethnicity, gender, and sexual orientation. A central goal of this course is to understand scientific and technical knowledge and pracctices as forms of knowledge that are situated within social spheres of difference. We think through notions like scientific objectivity and technological neutrality by examining how research is planned and conducted, and how genomic knowledge is applied in diverse fields like law, public health, pharmaceuticals, or reproductive technologies. The course develops skills to think critically about how genomics is reshaping the relationship between self and society, and the very nature of the social itself" - contending precisely with a technological challenge and the sustainability problems that it proposes!
column10: What are the genomic sciences and what impact are they having upon society? This course explores the impact of genomics—the study of genes and their functions—on society with a particular emphasis on India, China, and the U.S. where technological advances have outpaced regulatory oversight and social debate. The course develops skills to think critically about how genomics is reshaping the relationship between self and society, and the very nature of the social itself. The equivalent graduate course requires the final research paper to be about twice as long as the final research paper in this undergraduate course (10,000 vs. 5,000 words).

column9: "While algorithms have been with us throughout human history, we may be seeing, with advances in technology and artificial intelligence, something like an algorithmic acceleration in terms of their range and reach; adn their daily impact on many, if not most aspects of human socetiy... The course explores how deep-learning algorithms may undergird an intensification of surveillance and securitization technologies with profound effects on human and post-human futures"
column10: Algorithms are a series of step-by-step instructions in a procedure that finishes and which is shown to work in all cases. This course addresses the formation of algorithmic cultures through the domains of digitality and ontology in South Asia and the Middle East. It introduces students to the concepts of algorithmic neutrality, discrimination, management and governance. The course explores how deep-learning algorithms may undergird an intensification of surveillance and securitization technologies with profound effects on human and post-human futures

column9: More historical than thinking with contemporary issues.
column10: Chinese Art and Visual Culture is an introductory seminar studying the history of traditional Chinese art and visual culture from ancient times to the nineteenth century. This course draws upon masterpieces and monuments from both archaeological finds and museum collections, including bronze vessels, funeral objects, painting, calligraphy, sculptures, architecture, ceramics, and so on. Designed for students who have no background in Chinese art, Chinese history, or art history, the seminar uses diverse teaching materials in multiple media beyond traditional textbook-based readings to achieve four main goals: 1) Develop visual literacy through a direct encounter with objects. The development of specialized vocabulary to describe, analyze, and communicate function, composition, and meaning in art. 2) Understand major artistic movements of art and architecture within historical, social, political contexts. 3) Develop specialized knowledge in art from specific geographical locations (e.g. China), time periods, artists or artistic movements. 4) Evaluate and use primary and secondary source materials.
column11: Asian Studies, Art History, Medieval And Early Modern Studies

column9: No notable focus on sustainability
column10: This course explores a series of issues that are critically important for the medieval art of both China and northern Europe. Topics include materials and techniques; public and private art: commerce, technology and prints; art and motion; archaeology; paradise and hell; maps and space; the gaze; erotica; patronage; and multiculturalism.

column9: A seminar course that talks about contemporary China in the context of nationalism, globalization, politics, and activism. Although it doesn't necessarily zoom out" to broader challenges, it frames and helps us understand the broader picture by looking at China as a case study.
column10: This course explores the range of theories and empirical research methodologies from comparative political science, political-economy, and Asian studies commonly applied to understanding Chinese politics: political participation, political organizations, collective action and popular protest, political culture, and political institutional change. This course will be a seminar requiring weekly presentations, extensive readings at the graduate level in social science, and an original research paper. There is no prerequisite for this course, but participants are assumed to already possess extensive knowledge of Chinese history, culture, and society.

column9: Focuses on "changes over time in ideas of kinship, caste, race, class, religious, linguistic, and gender identity, in relations with communities of color in the Global North". The student learning outcomes include "gain[ing] a deeper understanding of a range of historical and theoretical perspectives on concepts such as diaspora, migration, multiculturalism, racialization, and citizenship"
column10: People of South Asian heritage constitute one of the largest, and most religiously, culturally, linguistically diverse diasporas in the world. This upper-division seminar examines the historical and contemporary experiences of South Asian men and women who established communities in Africa, the Americas, Australia, Europe, the Middle East, and Southeast Asia.

column9: Not notably sustainable; historical rather than contemporary focus
column10: The Indian Ocean World presents an enormously varied arena of cultural exchange and interaction spanning coastal regions of Africa, the Middle East, South and Southeast Asia and Australia. Course introduces the region by examining societies and empires shaped by voyages of exploration, religious pilgrimages, trading diasporas and forced migration.

column9: "The analysis will involve gender relations interacted with class, racial, and cultural conflicts as an important driving force of the evolution of the literate women tradition" - examining sexism and gendered inequality - but also, doing so from a historical perspective rather than a forward-facing one
column10: This course examines women's roles in Chinese literature as writers, readers, and characters, focusing particularly on the tension between women's lived bodily experiences and the cultural experiences inscribed on the female body and how, in the process, women have contrarily gendered patriarchal culture into their own. It will also touch on Chinese women's incorporation of the Western Tradition.

column9: "What role does energy play in social change in Asian societies? And what can the study of Asian societies tell us about the study of energy in general?" - thinking about economic globalization, world energy markets, energy efficient developments in transport and housing, and consumption patterns.
column10: Multi-disciplinary study of Asian countries and cultures as to a way to explain production, exchange, consumption and influence of energy on political, economic and social/cultural institutions, including energy security and energy policy formation and resource use theories. Assumes basic knowledge of history and politics of Asian societies and economies.

column9: No emphasis on climate in syllabus
column10: The physical processes governing the nature and behavior of the various Solar System bodies are discussed with a focus on the origins, evolution and fate of the Solar System and its parts. This broader context leads to a deeper understanding of the Earth as a life-supporting planet.

column4: Taught in Spring 2020, no syllabus available
column9: Description mentions global warming as a particular focus of the course, so it may be assumed that there is at least a section of the class devoted to climatae change.
column10: Introduction to astrophysical processes, particularly the effect of the Sun on the Earth. Possible effects of solar variability will be considered, especially global warming. The observational and theoretical basis of our current understanding will be presented.

column9: Includes some lessons on climate, but not necessarily "sustainability"
column10: Overview of the Earth and the solar system: structure, evolution, and dynamics. Includes non-calculus mathematics: algebra, logarithms and simple trigonometry, including Kepler's laws. Observing sessions at campus observatory and George Observatory ??. Designed for inservice and preservice science teachers (grades 4-12), but open to undergraduates considering a teaching career.

column9: No emphasis on climate or climate change
column10: The Sun, solar-terrestrial relationships, solar wind; planetary atmospheres, ionospheres and magnetospheres. Includes a research paper and presentation on a physical process in the solar system.

column5: Sustainable Water Purification For The Developing World
column9: From the course description alone, it is clear that this is a sustainability focused course. It is oriented around water, a key sustainability issue, and problem-solving related to this.
column10: This course is an overview of sustainable strategies for safe water supply in off-the-grid, low-income regions. Topics covered include water quality and treatment, sustainability and WASH (water, sanitation and hygiene). A major element of the course is a project to solve a water-related issue in a real-world context

column9: Focused more on the science than its application to sus challenges
column10: This course will introduce the students to modern biotechnology. The course will cover fundamental technologies with emphasis on modern genome engineering, sequencing and bioinformatics, molecular diagnostics, design of therapeutics, and recombinant microorganisms for industrial and environmental applications. The course includes discussion of bioethical issues, societal impact, and intellectual properties.

column9: Looking at "health economics, humanitarian emergencies, and appropriate health technology case studies" = concerned with ethical engagement with global health and the ways in which "humanitarian" efforts engage with these issues
column10: Seminar-style introductory design course covering epidemiology, pathophysiology, health systems, health economics, medical ethics, humanitarian emergencies, scientific and engineering design methods, and appropriate health technology case studies.

column5: Needs Finding And Development In Bioengineering
column9: "Engineers in the field of rehabilitation engineering are expected to identify patient needs and find creative, effective, and low-cost solutions to meet those nedds... Students will be exposed to the basic principles of engineering design, problem solving, and technical writing, while exploring the ever changing climate and regulations for patients with disabilities in American society." - aiming to problem solve, to address a health disparity, and to do so with efficiency
column10: Students in this course will learn and develop the engineering skill of needs finding in the field of bioengineering focused on designing for disabilities. Students will work in groups with patients with disabilities to identify daily needs and develop design criteria to meet those needs including preliminary prototype development

column9: Course contains applications, but none specific to sustainability-related challenges
column10: Design of biology at scales from molecules to multicellular organisms will be covered by lecture, primary literature, and student presentations. Students will execute a team based design challenge

column9: It is unclear whether this course should be included or not - It seems possible that it ought to be because it is aimed towards "mobile health" and resolving challenges in the area of health, but it would be helpful to know what past projects have entailed.
column10: This course will be an innovation lab for mobile health products. The students will organize themselves in groups with complementary skills and work on a single project for the whole semester. The aim will be to develop a product prototype which can then be demonstrated to both medical practitioners and potential investors. For successful projects with an operational prototype, the next steps could be applying for OWLspark (Rice accelerator program) or crowd sourcing (like Kickstarter) and/or work in Scalable Health Labs over summer. ELEC Juniors can also continue the project outcomes as a starting point for their senior design.

column9: No notable inclusion of sustainability issues based on dscription
column10: Emphasis will be placed on issues regarding the design, synthesis, evaluation, regulation and clinical translation of biomaterials for specific applications. An overview of significant biomaterials engineering applications will be given, including topics such as ophthalmologic, orthopedic, cardiovascular and drug delivery applications, with attention to specific case studies. Regulatory issues concerning biomaterial will also be addressed. Assignments for this class will include frequent readings of the scientific literature with occasional homework questions, one midterm and cumulative final, a group project, a seminar report and individual presentations

column9: Aimed towards troubleshooting and solving problems in health and health inequity
column10: Bioengineering course in the troubleshooting, repair, and maintenance of standard biomedical equipment used in hospitals in the developed and developing worlds.

column9: Syllabus is not very helpful. If design projects are focused specifically on addressing "problems" or challenges in the field of medicine and technology, I think this could be a focused course. However, it is difficult to tell with the info provided.
column10: Senior Bioengineering students will design devices in biotechnology or biomedicine. This project-based course covers systematic design processes, engineering economics, FDA requirements, safety, engineering ethics, design failures, research design, intellectual property rights, environmental impact, business planning and marketing. Students will be expected to compile documentation and present orally progress of their teams.

column9: See above
column10: Senior Bioengineering students will design devices in biotechnology or biomedicine. This project-based course covers systematic design processes, engineering economics, FDA requirements, safety, engineering ethics, design failures, research design, intellectual property rights, environmental impact, business planning and marketing. Students will be expected to compile documentation and present orally progress of their teams.

column9: Tropical medicine is not in itself a topic that addresses sus challenges, but the course descfiption is oriented towards the intersections of global development, poverty, and health inequity
column10: 8 week lecture series on topics in global health. The theme for this offering is one health; integrating efforts to obtain optimal health for humans, animals, and the environment. Offered in conjunction with the new National School of Tropical Medicine, the course will feature lectures by various experts on the public health issues most pressing in poor populations in the world today. Course open to all undergraduates and graduate students.

column9: Although the course description emphasizes that students will learn how biological network analysis can be used for downstream applications, the syllabus does not provide clarirty as to what those applications are enough for it to be said that they are sustainability related.
column10: This course covers computational aspects of biological network analysis, a major theme in the area of systems biology. The course discusses protein-protein interaction, signaling, metabolic, and functional networks, and covers issues related to constructing, analyzing various types of networks, as well as how they can be used for downstream applications

column9: More focused on the science than its application/relevance to sus challenges
column10: Introduction to concepts necessary for application of systems - Biology Approaches to Human Diseases. Topics include transcriptional and metabolic design principles, introduction to various regulatory network motifs in diseases and potential treatments using embryonic stem cells. Analysis of complex diseases using engineering concepts such as optimality, nonequilibrium thermodynamics, multiscale analysis and spatiotemporal transport.

column9: Objectives of the coures include "develop[ing] a solid understanding of the process of science and an appreciation for the credibility of scientific research and theories" and more generally, understanding and appreciating the validity of science. Specific topics addressed to this end include gender, health (vaccinations), and climate change. Applying science to solve problems and be an engaged citizen.
column10: Designer babies, climate change, the anti-vaccine movement, gender identity, evolution…exploring these and other socially relevant topics will provide a context for learning essential concepts in biology and ways to distinguish science truth from science fiction.

column9: Although it teaches towards ecological sciences and disciplines/themes, it does not focus on sustainbility in a notable way.
column10: This course provides a short introduction to the science of ecology and evolutionary biology. The topics covered include the mechanisms of evolution, the origin of species, the history of life on earth, biodiversity, animal behavior, population and community ecology, ecosystems, and conservation biology.

column9: No notable inclusion of sustainability issues - just basic biology
column10: The first in a series of two introductory biology courses (BIOS 201, BIOS 202). This course examines chemistry and energetics, cell physiology, cell biology, Mendelian genetics, molecular genetics, developmental biology, and plant physiology.

column9: Introduction to "the science of ecology and its various sub-disciplines including population ecology, community ecology, ecosystem ecology, and conservation biology" and aims to help students "gain a new perspective on humans, our evolutionary origins, and our relationship to the natural world" - but just learning about the environment does not automatically make it sustainability related!
column10: The second in a series of two introductory biology courses (BIOS 201, BIOS 202). This course examines the diversity of life, comparative animal physiology, evolution, ecology, and conservation. An emphasis is placed on evolution as a central framework necessary for a complete understanding of modern biology. Group discussions allow students to explore topics in more detail and discover how they are relevant to our everyday lives.

column9: "fudnamentals of urban agriculture with emphasis on community gardening and use of organic gardening techniques" - "urban agriculture [and] community garden programs can be an important tool in all levels of urban development". The course is focused on sustainable gardening practices, urban agriculture, and building community around gardening.
column10: The course introduces the fundamentals of community garden design and practice. Responsibilities will center on developing and improving the Rice Community Garden. A strong emphasis will be on learning and applying ecological principles to the practice of community agriculture. Class has required meetings outside of regular class time.

column9: More focused on the science/lab techniques than on specific problems or sustainbiilty hcallenges
column10: This course is only for Rice students conducting research for the first time. The students will conduct scientific research in the laboratories of the Rice faculty in Biosciences. During the five-week course, students will engage in full time research and will be mentored by experienced researchers under the supervision of Rice faculty. Participating students will also receive formal instruction on the basics of scientific research and innovation.

column9: Focused more on fundamental lab techniques than on specific problems, challenges, etc.
column10: Introduction to scientific method, principles of experimental design, selected research strategies, record keeping, and technical communication as related to biological science. The prereq BIOS 201 may be taken concurrently with BIOS 211. Registration restricted to current BioSciences majors (BCB, BIOS, EEB) and new BioSciences majors (with concentrations of Biochemistry, Cell Biology & Genetics, or Integrative Biology) for sections 001, 002, 003, 004, and 005. BCB minors can register for sections 007, 008, 009, 010, and 011.

column5: Introductory Lab In Ecology And Evolution
column9: "This itroductory laboratory course introduces students to the science of ecology and evolutionary biology through hands-on, inquiry-based, virtual laboratory exercises... provide experience in the fundamentals of natural history, data collection and analysis, and communication of results"  - More about fundamental lab techniques than solving problems related to sustainability
column10: Experimental, laboratory, and field studies of natural history, ecology, evolution, and animal behavior.

column9: "By the end of the course you will be expected to: 1) understand ecological concepts, 2) understand environmental laws and regulations, 3) understand the roles and relationships of state and federal agencies, NGOs (non-government organizations), industry/commercial business, and other organizations have managing different ecosystems, 4) understand methods to assess environmental impact and risk, 5) understand methods to collect, assess, and monitor environmental field data and implement mitigation, 6) be able to communicate in written assignments" - talking specifically about the environemnt and environmental management in various capacities
column10: This course will focus on applied ecosystem topics including relations with state and federal agencies, filed studies, wetland delineations, permitting compliance, and environmental regulations.

column4: Taught Fall 2020 but no syllabus available
column9: From the description alone, it is clear that the course is focused around the main themes of sustainability and addressing sustainabiity challenges.
column10: Sustainable development is an approach to development based on interacting social, economic, and environmental forces. It is intended as methodology for planning, and a guiding principle for Environmental Health and safety compliance (EHSs) and Corporate Sustainability (CSRs). Students will learn compliance guidelines, risk management, and assessment considerations.

column5: Paradigms In Biochemistry And Cell Biology
column9: Focused more on fundamental biological knowledge, no evnrionmental or problem-solving components
column10: This course examines paradigms in biochemistry and cell biology with a specific focus on the “central dogma” of molecular biology and is designed for BIOS majors and minors and recommended strongly for students with Advanced Placement in Biology who do not take BIOS 201 and for students wanting additional foundation before transitioning to other 300-level BIOS lecture courses. Using a “flipped” format, lectures are available online, and in-class activities address confusions/questions, examine both historic and contemporary research papers, explore cases and problems, and engage students in short writing assignments.

column9: "BIOS 311 further advances basic laboratory, record keeping, and technical communication skills that were introduced and/or reinforced in BIOS 211... Our emphasis is on the process of science (i.e., fundamental abilities and skills) rather than the content (i.e. discipline-specific lab techniques)"
column10: Advancement of biochemical laboratory methods, record keeping, technical communication skills, and research strategies. Students will maintain a research quality laboratory notebook and will submit a paper in the style of a journal article.

column5: Advanced Communication In The Biological Sciences
column9: "this two-credit course focuses on improving students' abilities to communicate scientific topics to various audiences through written, oral, and visual media"
column10: This course will focus on improving students’ written and oral communication skills. Emphasis will be placed on communication of scientific topics for audiences ranging from experts to the general public through weekly assignments.

column9: This course provides an introduction to ecological research, both in methods and in practice. Many field trips are presented on the syllabus that are meant to help students gain experience with hands-on work in the environment. However, just looking at the environment and topics such as "forest succession" and "exotic plant invasions" doesn't make the class sustainability driven, does it?
column10: Field and lab experiments in ecology. Class has required meetings outside of regular class time.

column9: An ecology lab module, but not focused on sustainability per se.
column10: Examine first-hand the two most diverse ecosystems on earth - the coral reef and the tropical rainforest in this 2-week summer course in the Central American country of Belize. Topics will include the diversity of tropical organisms and habitats, the formation of coral reefs, rainforest ecology, historical biogeography, symbiosis, and conservation of tropical biodiversity. While a background in biology is desirable, individuals lacking this background but having a special interest in the tropics are encouraged to enroll. Includes a course fee that covers all transportation, accommodation, and meals.

column9: An ecology lab module, but no notable focus on sustainability beyond "environmental management" mentioned in the description - but this is not enough to justify inclusion.
column10: This course consists of a 2-week trip to Brazil to examine first-hand the ecology of the largest wetland ecosystem on earth - the Pantanal. Days will be spent in the field making observations and collecting data; lectures in the evenings will cover topics including freshwater ecology, seasonal flooding dynamics, community ecology of wetland species, symbiosis, geology, environmental management, ecotourism, and conservation biology. Includes a course fee that covers all transportation, accommodations, and meals.

column9: "This course will introduce you to key concepts involved in understanding behaviors, inclueding those involved in survival, mating and reproduction; in cooperation and conflict; and in interactions within and between species. In order to understand why animals behave in the ways that they do, we will fcus on ways that evolution has shaped behaviors, integrating ideas from psychology, economics and genetics" - not focused on sustainability or sustainability challenges
column10: Evolutionary theory is used to evaluate behavioral adaptations of organisms to their environment.

column9: "This one-credit laboratory course is designed to address an authentic, local conservation issue facing the greater Houston area. Students will be responsible for the project design, the collection and analysis of data, and the dissemination of that data". The first expected achievement at the end of the course is that students will "understand methods used to investigate and analyze biodiversity, witha  focus on the challenges of working in urban settings". Another is to "understand the role that urban conservation has in encouraging awareness in regards to habitat loss and global species decline" - focusing on challenges, problems, and problem solving
column10: This course will give students hands-on experiences in the practice of conservation biology through authentic projects related to prioritization and design of nature preserves, restoration of natural environments, and for monitoring threatened and endangered species in the Houston area. BIOS 423 may be taken concurrently with EBIO 322.

column9: Course objectives inclued "the expertise to distinguish among the best approaches for conserving biological diversity and some of the contemporary tools", "the ability to describe both successful and unsuccessful case studies of conservation efforts and discern charactersitics of each," "a clear notion of how society shapes conservation efforts, including the forces of economics, policy, ethics, and institutions," and "a familiarity with the current issues, controversies, and dilemmas within the field of conservation biology" - focused on environmental problems and solutions
column10: he course is designed to give students a broad overview of conservation biology. Lecture and discussions will focus on conservation issues such as biodiversity, extinction, management, sustained yield, invasive species and preserve design.

column9: Two objectives of the course are the expectation of students to know "some of the ways that biologists use insects in their research; and why insects are important to people". Two readings are relevant to environment/ecology/climate change, but it is not enough of an emphasis in my opinion to warrant inclusion.
column10: This course addresses contemporary issues in ecology and evolution through the lens of insect diversity. Readings span a broad literature (popular to technical). Writing and oral reports develop proficiency in scientific communication.

column9: "This is a one-credit laboratory course focused on identifying, quantifying, and analyzing biological diversity... Guest presentations by experts will provide additional insights and perspectives on biological diversity, including how it is measured, why it is important, and the efforts being made to preserve it in diverse ecosystems". Only one eweek of the semester is dedicated to "Ecology, behavior, and conservation" - however, it is a one-credit course, so one week is still significant. In addition, students are required to develop "species accounts" as part of the class that include the conservation status of the species in their taxonomic group - conservation is part of how the course was framed.
column10: This laboratory course focuses on the theory and practice of estimating biodiversity. Students work in groups to design, execute, and communicate the results of a systematic survey of particular taxonomic groups in the Big Thicket National Preserve in east Texas.

column9: One of the learning objectives is "understand the ecology of animals including biogeography and conservation" - however, the class in general is more focused on animal diversity and the science of it than challenges, sustainability, etc.
column10: The evolution and systematics of the animal kingdom with consideration of functional anatomy, comparative physiology, behavior, medical implications and resource management.

column9: An important objective of the course is to understand "why insects are important including their ecological, economic, and cultural value" and "how entomological collections controibute to agricultural, ecological, and medical research" - but more about lab techniques than sustainability/challenges
column10: Hands-on experiences with collection and curation of insects.

column9: Morer about the science than about sustainability and challengesproblem-solving
column10: Study of population dynamics, species interactions, plant and animal community organization, and ecosystem function.

column9: Morer about the science than about sustainability and challengesproblem-solving
column10: Principles of biological evolution. Topics include natural selection, adaptation, molecular evolution, formation of new species, the fossil record, biogeography, and principles of classification.

column9: The course aims to teach "the roles that plants play in their natural environments - how they interact with one another, with other members of their communities, and their local abiotic environments", "some of the ways that biologists use plants in their research", and "the economic and cultural roles of plants in shaping modern human society" - but still, more ffocused on the science than challenges/problem-solving
column10: The evolution, systematics, and ecology of plants, with emphasis on flowering plants and biodiversity.

column9: More focused on learning about birding as a practice than sustainability issues or problems related to birds/birding
column10: This course centers on a series of five field trips to diverse habitats for observing birds both immigrants and residents. Each will be preceded by a lecture and students will do two projects. Class has required meetings outside of regular class time.

column9: The course objectives include teaching students "how botanical collections contribute to agricultural, ecological, and evolutionary research" and "why plants are important including their ecological, economic, and cultural value," but the class is more focused on the science of plants than their relation to sustainability.
column10: This course will complement the BIOS 336 course by providing hands-on experience in the science of botany. Students will become familiar with the anatomy, physiology, evolution and biodiversity of plants through lab dissections, microscopy, and field observations.

column9: More focused on the science than on sustainability
column10: This course takes a comparative approach to investigate animal physiology of vertebrates. Students learn how animals are adapted to their environments, including how they meet their energy needs, take up and transport oxygen, and maintain hydration and salt balance. Students read primary literature to explore survival in extreme environments.

column9: More focused on the science than on sustainability
column10: In BIOS 350 students conduct investigative studies in the areas of biological science, neuroscience, natural history, ecology, evolution, and/or animal behavior. These studies may encompass original research, instructor-designed experiments, and/or online projects with curated data, depending on the availability of in-person laboratory and/or field experiences. BIOS 350 further advances basic laboratory and/or field experiences, record keeping abilities, and technical communication skills that were introduced and/or reinforced in the intermediate lab course. This course is available to students who cannot reasonably be expected to complete an advanced lab requirement for any major concentration in Biosciences and will substitute for that course requirement, subject to approval by the instructors of the course to be replaced and the BioSciences Undergraduate Curriculum Committee.

column9: Readings and topics are often speculative in nature, thinking about the future, technology, biology, and the human body. However, the class is not really focused towards sustainability challenges or framing our understanding of them (beyond bettering our understanding of difference in general).
column10: Across variations of life, we draw boundaries between normal, not normal, and monstrous. From the Biosciences to the Creative Arts, our conceptions of the "monstrous" illuminate our identity, perceptions, and fears. Discussion-based class accessible to people of all backgrounds and interests.

column9: Focused more on the sciencce than its relevance to sustainability challenges
column10: Cellular and molecular basis of innate and adaptive immune function in mammals.

column9: The reef-environment interaction aspect of the class is interesting, but not specific enough to sustainability to warrant inclusion.
column10: This three credit lecture course introduces students to a complex, dynamic and sensitive ecosystem: coral reefs. We will explore the biotic and abiotic components of coral reefs; how reef organisms interact with each other and the environment, and the factors that contribute to reef construction and decline over time and space.

column9: One of the main goals of the couse is to explain "the physiological and environmental causes of genetic variations... we will mainly focus on molecular mechanisms of hereditary genetic diseases, neurodegenerative diseases, cancer and environmentally induced diseases" - however, more focused on the science than its relation to sustainability
column10: The course intends to provide in-depth knowledge of the molecular basis of human diseases. We will discuss: 1) Different types of genetic variations that may lead to human diseases; 2) The various approaches to investigate the molecular basis of human diseases; 3) The molecular and cellular consequences of disease-associated genetic variations; 4) The physiological and environmental causes of genetic variations; 5) The molecular basis for disease diagnosis and treatments. We will mainly focus on molecular mechanisms of inherent genetic diseases, neurodegenerative diseases, cancer and environmentally induced diseases. This will be a combined lecture/discussion course. The class materials are mainly based on preliminary literatures and case studies. Students are expected to actively participate in discussion in class and to give presentations and lectures based on research paper

column9: The course objectives include "the ability to discern the primary threats to biodiversity", "the expertise to ditinguish among the best approaches for conserving biological diversity and some of the contemporary tools," "a clear notion of how society shapes conservation efforts, including the forces of economics, policy, ethics, and institutions", "a familiarity with the current issues, controversies and dilemmas within the field of conservation biology". A core component of the class is a group project that involves problem solving/making aporposal to the Texas Nature Conservancy about how Rice "could increase the local and regional diversity of pollinators". .
column10: This course is designed to give students a broad overview of conservation biology. Lecture and discussions will focus on conservation issues such as biodiversity, extinction, management, sustained yield, invasive species and preserve design. Counts as a capstone course for the major concentration in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology.

column9: The course objectives focus on the environmental importance of microbes: "students will develop knowledge of the microbial processes used in production of various foods and the moleuclar basis of diagnostic test systems used for industrial optimization and monitoring, environmental assessment and health diagnostic applications" and "students will be able to analyze and comunicate key factors about pathogenic agents and the mechanisms by which they create disease symptoms and be able to consider appropriate methods for treatment, public health response and impact of major types of infectious diseases". There is also a specifici and dedicated section of the course devoted to the environmental relevance of microbes, particularly in terms of their potential as fuels, their impact on mining and ores, etc. A project in this unit also involves taking the role of the EPA to look at past environmental challenges related to microbes. The whole of the course relates to sustainability challenges including health, environmental change, and the development of industry (future)
column10: Structure and functions of microorganisms with emphasis on their environmental, industrial and medical importance.

column9: The objectives of the course are that "students will develop and demonstrate understanding of plant development and signaling pathways and key techniques used in plant molecular genetic research and biotechnology. In individual projects, students will critically evaluate primary literature on genetic modifications used to enhance plant properties for environmental, nutritional, or commercial benefit"   - the project component in my opinion warrants inclusion as it is oriented towards problem solving with an environmental focus
column10: Novel aspects of plant biology and development with emphasis on molecular and genetic mechanisms. Plant responses to the environment and the use of bioengineering and other means to develop new plant products will also be covered.

column9: Although health inequities and health justice are sustainability challenges, this course does not seem to teach towards those aims per se.
column10: This course gives a broad overview of the biology of infectious diseases using examples from humans, plants, and animals. Topics include diversity of diseases, mechanisms of disease transmission, epidemiology, population regulation, evolution of virulence, disease dynamics in natural communities and disease invasion and conservation biology.

column9: The course in 2021 covered the topic of "One Health which includes understanding the connections between people, nature and our shared environment. Remaining topics will be decided with input from class" - this topic is certainly related to sustainability challenges, but the fact that the course in general is so free form and not known makes me hesitant.
column10: This course provides an integration of interdisciplinary topics that span environmental sciences. Topics will vary depending upon the interests and needs of both students and faculty.

column9: "What drives the development of new disruptive platforms for processing payments, loans or investments? What are the sources of funding for disruptors? How are Asian fintech dragons redefining financial services through e-commerce and social payments? HOw are these new technologies democratizing access and improving financial inclusion?" - after finishing this course, student should "understand how the blockchain revolution has the potential to impact society and the economy".  However, the class is more about the business side of things than the challenges/sustainability side.
column10: Are financial services the next industry to be brought to its knees by disruptors and blockchain technology? Analyze how the likes of Square, PayPal, Stripe, Lending Club, OnDeck or Robinhood are disrupting financial services. Look into the next wave of technologies which are likely to accelerate the disruption: blockchain, cryptocurrencies and robotics.

column9: Two important goals of the course are to discus the "challenges healthcare faces" and "important opportunities for healthcare executives to alter the current value equation through changes in organizational behavior, operations, strategy, technology and policy." In 2020, the course also dealt with the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on "an already strained system." Course focuses on health, health inequity, and problem solving in this arena.
column10: This course will serve as an introduction to the U.S. healthcare system from a business perspective. We will describe the providers and the financial system that comprise healthcare, and the challenges healthcare faces. We will explore opportunities to increase quality while decreasing costs and the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on an already strained system.

column9: From the foundation of the course, which deals with "analyzing and engaging the sphere of social entrepreneurship," students will engage in a project or "social entrepreneurship study about a contemporary social problem in Houston: Food insecurity. Students will learn about food insecurity from a series of speakers, readings, and a field project experience with an organization .Working with that organization, students will study, analyze, critique, and offer suggestions for improvements." - focused on civic engagement work that aims to solve sustainabilty challenges, and students themsleves work on a challenge through the food insecuirty study.
column10: This course introduces students to contemporary concepts, debates, and contexts necessary for analyzing and engaging in the sphere of social entrepreneurship. The course has four distinct parts: social context; organizational forms and collaborations; private sector roles; and measurement and impacts. Various aspects of social entrepreneurship, such as base of the pyramid/microenterprises, private-public partnerships, private-governmental partnerships, voluntary social codes, corporate social responsibility, and ethical consumerism will be covered. From this foundation, students will undertake a social entrepreneurship project about a contemporary social problem in Houston: food insecurity and food deserts.

column9: More focused on the business side than its applications to sustainability
column10: Students will identify, screen, and evaluate start-ups for investment by the Rice venture capital fund. Through this highly experiential course, students will learn tools for rigorously evaluating startup ventures for investment, valuing early stage companies, and structuring investments. Students will present their investment recommendations to an advisory committee.

column9: Class focuses on learning code within Python and MATLAB but does not focus on applying it to social problems/ for social good.
column10: Modeling, Simulation, and Visualization via MATLAB. Numerical methods: Newton's method in one and several dimensions. Gaussian elimination and optimization. Application to problems in science and engineering. Lectures are held Monday and Wednesdays. In a laboratory component held on Fridays, students work in small groups on computational projects led by a Rice Learning Assistant.

column9: No indication of sustainability focus or inclusivity.
column10: Equilibria and the solution of linear systems and linear least squares problems. Eigenvalue problem and its application to solve dynamical systems. Singular value decomposition and its application.

column5: Differential Equations In Science And Engineering
column9: No indication of sustainability focus or inclusivity.
column10: Classical and numerical solution techniques for ordinary and partial differential equations. Fourier series and the finite element method for initial and boundary value problems arising in diffusion and wave propagation phenomena.

column9: Focuses on optimization methods in a sole mathematical sense.
column10: Formulation of mathematical models of complex decisions arising in management, economics, and engineering. Models using linear, nonlinear, stochastic and integer programming, as well as networks. Linear programming duality and its modeling implications. Overview of basic solution methods for these optimization models.

column9: Combines elements of neuroscience with bioengineering and mathematical optimization. However, syllabus does not indicate any sense of sustainability focus in curriculum.
column10: We present the theoretical foundations of cellular and systems neuroscience from distinctly quantitative point of view. We develop the mathematical and computational tools as they are needed to model, analyze, visualize and interpret a broad range of experimental data.

column9: PDE deals with electrostatics, electrodynamics, fluid flow, elasticity, or quantum mechanics which COULD deal with sustainability, but has no application of it.
column10: First order of partial differential equations. The method of characteristics. Analysis of the solutions of the wave equation, heat equation and Laplace's equation. Integral relations and Green's functions. Potential theory, Dirichlet and Neumann problems. Asymptotic methods: the method of stationary phase, geometrical optics, regular and singular perturbation methods.

column9:
Has a focus on conservation laws and fundamental principles in
modeling various physical phenomena, but no application to sustainability.
column10: Derivation and properties of solutions of the partial differential equations of continuum physics. Basic concepts of continuum mechanics, ideal fluids, Navier-Stokes equations, linear elasticity, acoustics, basic principles of thermodynamics, Newtonian heat flow, porous flow, Maxwell's equations, electrical circuits.

column9: Does not talk about numerical analysis of algorithms beyond the actual mathematics of it.
column10: Construction and application of numerical algorithms for root finding, interpolation and approximation of functions, quadrature, and the solution of differential equations; fundamentals of computer arithmetic; solution of linear systems, linear least squares problems, and eigenvalue problems via matrix factorizations; Newton and Newton-like methods for nonlinear systems of equations. Computer programming in MATLAB is required.

column9: The whole class is programming. Could argue that they maybe talk about sustainable investment in portfolios, but not sure.
column10: Portfolio optimization and asset allocation models. Risk management and option pricing. Deterministic and stochastic optimization approaches, as well as linear and nonlinear approaches will be used to model decisions arising in finance.

column9: Only geometry and optimization, no sustainability.
column10: Linear and integer programming involve formulating and solving fundamental optimization models widely used in practice. This course introduces the basic theory, algorithms, and software of linear and integer programming. Topics studied in the linear programming part include polyhedron concepts, simplex methods, duality, sensitivity analysis and decomposition techniques. Building on linear programming, the second part of this course introduces modeling with integer variables and solution methodologies in integer programming including branch-and-bound and cutting-plane techniques. This course will provide a basis for further studies in convex and combinatorial optimization.

column9: This is a class to learn how to teach, and it doesn't have a sustainability focus or component.
column10: This course is designed to support Rice Learning Assistants (RLAs) as they instruct their own lab sections of CAAM 210. Topics include analysis of computational science and engineering concepts, issues of problem-based learning (PBL), theories of learning, and fundamental teaching skills.

column9: Some projects could deal with sustainability and solving these problems through optimization methods.
column10: Students engage in team-oriented year-long design projects that utilize modeling, analysis, and scientific computing skills to solve a problem motivated by an application in engineering or the physical, biological, or social sciences.

column9: Deals with inequality and the underrepresentation of minorities in STEM field. Also talks about potential solutions to engage this group of students. Deals with topics of racism and inequality.
column10: The class will read from Tapia's text: Losing the Precious Few: How America Fails to Educate Minorities in Science and Engineering and then discuss in class issues associated with the underrepresentation of Blacks and Hispanics in academic and national science and engineering activities. Topics will include racism, immigration, student admissions, faculty hiring, faculty promotion, the role of minority serving institutions, mistaking foreign minorities for the Precious Few, support issues and leadership.

column9: Talks about math in a pure way, no sustainability component.
column10: Real numbers, completeness, sequences and convergence, compactness, continuity, the derivative, the Riemann integral, fundamental theorem of calculus. Vector spaces, dimension, linear maps, inner products and norms, derivatives in R^d, inverse function theorem, implicit function theorem, multiple integration, change of variable theorem.

column9: Introduces students to C, C+ and C++, but does not go beyond introductory programming.
column10: Scientific programming using high level languages, including C, Fortran, and C++. Emphasis on use of numerical libraries. Basic techniques of project planning, source management, documentation, program construction, i/o, visualization. Object-oriented design for numerical computing.

column9: Nothing shows a sustainability component.
column10: First order of partial differential equations. The method of characteristics. Analysis of the solutions of the wave equation, heat equation and Laplace's equation. Integral relations and Green's functions. Potential theory, Dirichlet and Neumann problems. Asymptotic methods: the method of stationary phase, geometrical optics, regular and singular perturbation methods. Additional coursework is required beyond the undergraduate course requirements.

column9: Nothing shows a sustainability component.
column10: This course combines basic physical principles with vector calculus to derive many important partial differential equations governing motion of fluids and solids. Topics include stress, strain, idealized fluids, linear elasticity, acoustics, basics of thermodynamics, Navier-Stokes.

column9: Nothing shows a sustainability component.
column10: Construction and application of numerical algorithms for root finding, interpolation and approximation of functions, quadrature, and the solution of differential equations; fundamentals of computer arithmetic; solution of linear systems, linear least squares problems, and eigenvalue problems via matrix factorizations; Newton and Newton-like methods for nonlinear systems of equations. Computer programming in MATLAB is required

column9: Nothing shows a sustainability component.
column10: Construction and analysis of numerical algorithms for root finding, interpolation and approximation of functions, quadrature, and the solution of differential equations; fundamentals of computer arithmetic; solution of linear systems, least squares problems, and eigenvalue problems via matrix factorizations; the singular value decomposition (SVD) and basic sensitivity analysis. Computer programming in MATLAB is required.

column9: Nothing shows a sustainability component.
column10: Derivation and application of necessity conditions and sufficient conditions for constrained optimization problems.

column9: Nothing shows a sustainability component.
column10: This course covers the same lecture material as CAAM 471, but fosters greater theoretical sophistication through more challenging problem sets and exams.

column9: Nothing shows a sustainability component.
column10: Measure-theoretic foundations of probability. Open to qualified undergraduates. Required for PhD students in statistics.

column5: Intro To Random Processes And Application
column9: Nothing shows a sustainability component.
column10: Review of basic probability; Sequences of random variables; Random vectors and estimation; Basic concepts of random processes; Random processes in linear systems, expansions of random processes; Wiener filtering; Spectral representation of random processes, and white-noise integrals.

column9: Could have sustainability focus?
Nothing shows a sustainability component.
column10: We present the theoretical foundations of cellular and systems neuroscience from distinctly quantitative point of view. We develop the mathematical and computational tools as they are needed to model, analyze, visualize and interpret a broad range of experimental data. Additional coursework required beyond the undergraduate course requirements.

column5: Fundamentals Of Civil And Environmental Engineering
column9: One learning objective of the class is to "possess increased awareness of current environmental issues". The course will also "weave a broader theme on Smarter Cities with Smart INfrastructure. More than half the world's population lives in a city context, and in the next 20 years about three billion people are expected to move into city and urban environments... Topics may include smart infrastructure for increased sustainability and resiliency; The smart and aging infrastructure nexus; smart infrastructure and public policy; big data technology and the Internet-of-Things (IoT)" - the inclusion of this theme and its focus on CEVE's ability to problem-solve
column10: This introduction will cover the essential topics and quantitative techniques in civil and environmental engineering. General engineering, engineering math, fluid mechanics, hydrology, statistics, and mass balance techniques will be presented followed by applications.

column5: Wild Topics In Chemistry And Nanotechnology
column9: Not specific enough to wararnt inclusion based on description. 100th no.
column10: A variety of topics related to chemistry and nanotechnology will be discussed. Some topics are classical while others are current. Topics may include nanocars, molecular electronics, how to form a start-up company. Grades will be based upon attendance and quizzes.

column9: Engineering economics is not necessarily focused on sustainability - more a business-oriented perspective.
column10: Life cycle economics analysis to project development, project economic analysis, contracting, network scheduling, risk management, organizational structures and cases.

column9: "an introduction to sustainabile development and sustainable design.... required for the Minor in Energy and Water Sustainability.... designed to provide an understanding of the basic principles of sustainable development and how to integrate these concepts into design"
column10: The objective of this course is to develop skills in formulating and solving problems of societal development and advancement in light of increasing material, energy and water demands and decreasing resource availability. Sustainable design requires balancing economic, ecological/environmental and social issues to create physical as well as social structures that will work for current and future generations. In addition to learning to apply sustainable design principles to individual engineering and developing projects, students will be challenged to understand the application of sustainable design thinking a the municipal and corporate level.

column9: "Securing sufficient, reliable, and affordable supplies of energy in an environmentally sustainabile manner is among the greatest challenges facing society in this century. Appreciating and addressing this complex challenge requires consideration of the various physical, technological, and societal forces that shape enrgy use and its impact on the environment. This course will explore the phsyical principles of energy and how various sectors and fuels impact Earth's environment and climate." - the course is framed around sustainability challenges, learning about them, and solving them.
column10: This course explores the physical principles of energy use and its impacts on Earth's environment and climate. Topics will include energy mechanics, climate change, and the environmental impacts and future prospects of various fossil fuel and alternative energy sources.

column9: Course objectives include learning "the sources, effects, and control legislation fo air pollution," "how meteorology affects air pollution," "fundamentals of models that are used to understand air pollution and design control strategies," and "theory, design, and operation of control technologies for criteria pollutants and their precursors". The ABET student ouotcomes include "an ability to apply engineering design to produce solutions that meet specified needs with considertion of public health, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors" - the class is focused on science as a tool to solve a sustainability challenge.
column10: This course will discuss the history of air pollution and its effects as motivation for control of anthropogenic emissions to the atmosphere. Topics will include air pollution control strategies and regulations, predictive pollution concentration models, general ideas to reduce air pollution, and specific technologies to limit emissions of criteria pollutants and their precursors.

column9: After providing an introduction to basic principles of engineering, parts II and III of the course address "water pollution and control, with focus on common drinking water pollutants and treatment techniques" and "air pollution and control, with focus on the criteria pollutants of the Clean Air Act, atmospheric stability and meteorology, pollutant dispersion and the Gaussian Plume, the greenhosue effect, and stratospheric ozone depletion"
column10: This course covers principles of water quality engineering, air pollution control and solid and hazardous waste management. Elements of risk assessment, global atmospheric change, and pollution prevention are also addressed to contribute to adequate-level competency in Environmental Engineering.

column5: Uncertainty And Risk In Urban Infrastructures
column9: Guided by a sustainability challenge (urban housing and hazards posed to infrastructure)
column10: This course explores methods for practical risk-based decision support, particularly for infrastructure systems. Uncertainty quantification (UQ) to external events including natural hazards is at the core of risk-informed design, operation, and mitigation actions. UQ also guides engineering practice and enables code developments. The course emphasizes decision theory, Bayesian approaches, risk analysis tools, and infrastructure safety

column5: Sustainable Water Purification For The Developing World
column9: From the course description alone, it is clear that this is a sustainability focused course. It is oriented around water, a key sustainability issue, and problem-solving related to this.
column10: This course is an overview of sustainable strategies for safe water supply in off-the-grid, low-income regions. Topics covered include water quality and treatment, sustainability and WASH (water, sanitation and hygiene). A major element of the course is a project to solve a water-related issue in a real-world context

column9: The focus on water systems and water treatment cerrtainly relates to sustainabiliyt, as does the course objective of "analyz[ing] future integrated water management technology needs" - but it is not specifically/wholly oriented around challenges and sustainability of water treatmen
column10: This course will introduce urban water systems, including water sources, treatment processes, distribution and collection systems, and resource recovery and reuse. Student will learn the principles of physical, chemical, and biological processes, operations and reactor configurations commonly used for water quality control. In addition, students will learn analysis and design of specific water treatment and resource recovery processes and operations.

column9: Focused more on the sciecne than its relevance to sustainability - but if it is the lab of the previous class (CEVE 315), must it automatically count?
column10: This course will introduce measurement of physicochemical water quality parameters. The principles behind the measurements and the significance of measured values will be covered . Selected conventional and advanced water treatment techniques will be introduced with emphasis on experimental design, group problem solving, and report writing.

column9: Several readings and discussion topics focus on company ethics related to sustainability challenges, including environmental health, safety, gender inequality, and technology.
column10: Seminar introduces students to a framework for discussing and making ethical engineering and professional decisions. Using case studies and exercises, students will look at their own profession and its Engineering Code of Ethics as well as at the issues and risks they may face as managers and executives.

column9: From the course description, seems to focus more on the business side of things than how business and sustainability can converge in engineering disciplines.
column10: Introduction to the evaluation of alternative investment opportunities with emphasis on engineering projects and capital infrastructure. Time value of money concepts are developed in the context of detailed project evaluation and presentations. In addition, concepts and applications of risk analysis and investment under uncertainty are introduced. Requires oral and written presentations by students.

column9: From the course description, it is already clear that the course is focused on sustainability challenges, and specifically on addressing these challenges through class discussion and projects
column10: This course applies principles learned in CEVE 302/502 to real-world sustainability projects. Three to four case studies will comprise the class. These case studies will involve development of design solutions for (1) carbon neutral design, (2) ecosystem services transactions, (3) sustainable industrial applications and/or (4) air pollution and environmental justice.

column9: More focused on the science than its application to sustainability challenges
column10: Advanced topics in solid mechanics and strength of materials including energy methods, principle of virtual work, conservation laws, constitutive modeling, aspects of elasticity theory, stability and fracture mechanics with application to the analysis and design of reliable structures.

column9: A week of the course is debvoted to science and climate change ,and several more to environmental pollutants.
column10: Topics include: introductory concepts of general chemistry; applied physical chemistry; and organic and biochemical concepts as used in the profession.

column9: Course aims to explain what aerosols are, what their impacts are on the climate, and why we should care about them.
column10: Description and examination of the processes determining the chemical and physical characteristics of atmospheric aerosol particles. Important focal points include aerosol measurements and control techniques and aerosol climate effects. Most attention will be paid to processes active in the troposphere, but important differences between the troposphere and stratosphere are addressed.

column9: Focused not just on environmental law, but also about the future of this field and how it can be used to deal with climate change and sustainability
column10: Introduction to Environmental Law is intended to introduce the student to the methods used by the United States and the international community to regulate and/or allocate air, water and land resources. A key focus of this course will be the emerging area of the law of sustainable development, including the implementation of full price costing, life cycle analysis, carbon cycle analysis, allocation of assimilative capacity and other similar issues.

column9: Two of the four key topics of the class are focused on sustainability related challenges: 'cliamte change" and "air pollution". "While we will emphasize the chemical and physical processes that drive these phenomena, we will aslo consider their societal impacts and policies and technologies that can help address them". Allthough specific sections of the class are clearly sustainabile, the class's focus in general seems to thus be on sustainability-environment related questions.
column10: Study of the chemical and physical processes that govern the formation, transformation, and transport of gases and particles in the atmosphere. Overview of urban and regional air pollution, including tropospheric ozone formation and particulate matter; stratospheric chemistry; and global climate change.

column9: A section at the end of the course "will also cover the current state of flood policy and discuss innovative strategies for tackling flood-related issues and adapting to changes in flood risk over time". The course is oriented around flooding as a sustainaability issue.
column10: The purpose of this course is to introduce the student to the fundamentals of the hydrologic cycle, surface water, open channel flow concepts, and water resources. The course will introduce concepts related to the hydrologic cycle in urban and natural watersheds, rainfall runoff and hydrograph response, overland and channel flood routing, open channel flow, and the basics of floodplain. At the end of the semester, we will also cover the current state of flood policy, flood disasters, and discuss innovative strategies for tackling flood-related issues and adapting to changes in flood risk over time. There will be significant emphasis on applying and solving the governing equations, calculations and models to analyze water balance, and hydrologic and hydraulic response to severe rainfall events. Student participation and a completion of a HEC-HMS modeling exercise will be expected. Case studies will be presented and discussed near end of the class.

column9: The course description makes it clear that the course is sustainability focused. The core theme of the course is sustainabile development and sustainable design.
column10: This course is an introduction to sustainable development and sustainable design. Sustainable development is one of the most interesting and challenging issues facing the world today. Sustainability is about living within the limits of natural and human systems as well as working to ensure that future generations have the ability to meet their needs even as we ensure that current generations can meet theirs. Sustainability is about social issues as well as environmental and economic ones. Sustainability either is or will become an issue of primary concern to virtually every country, state, city, corporation and institution in the world over the next decade or two. Upon completion of this course, you will be able to enter into the dialogue about sustainable human systems.

column9: Potentially inclusive, as the description notes that the course will focus on "groundwater policy - use and landowner rights; and the future of groundwater management"
column10: The course will cover the fundamental principles of groundwater flow, including moisture flow in the unsaturated zone; aquifer testing and interpretation of field data; sustainable production of groundwater for public water supplies; models of groundwater flow in the saturated and unsaturated zones; groundwater policy – use and landowner rights; the future of groundwater management.

column9: "The objective of this class is to provide you with the knowledge of the processes, chemicals, technologies, and institutional consideratiosn that you need to select an appropriate method for cleaning up contaminated soil, groundwater, sediment, and surface water that has become adversely impacted by chemicals" - fundamentally concerned with sustainability
column10: Remediation principles and application of full-scale remediation technologies for restoration of contaminated soil, groundwater, and surface water.
