Topics include mass balances and distribution of chemicals in environmental media; development of remediation goals through risk assessment; treatment technology selection criteria and costs; groundwater, soil, and surface water restoration technologies; and regulatory considerations.

column9: "This course is about thinking how engineered systems fail, how to qualify the odds of such failures, and learning from contingencies to design new or retrofit existing systems". Case studies in the class will include "power systems, water networks, wind turbines, bridges, and buildings" - although these topics are sustainability adjacent, they are not framed as such in the class - rather, it is focused on learning the science behind them.
column10: Students will learn computational simulation and theoretical techniques for the reliability assessment of engineered systems as a function of their component failure probabilities. We will explore time-dependent and algorithmic system reliability, and will use modern structural infrastructure systems as case studies, including power systems, wind turbines, bridges, and buildings.

column9: Using engineering to solve challenges related to sustainability
column10: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the concept of smart materials and their application to address challenges in environmental engineering. The course will cover three broad categories of smart materials, namely self-healing materials, stimuli-responsive materials, and materials with molecular-recognition capabilities. The use of these materials for structural, sensing, water treatment, and energy applications will be highlighted. The course will emphasize the underlying chemical and thermodynamic principles driving the behavior and responses of smart materials.

column9: Syllabus has no notable focus on sustainabiity - rather, focused on the science and engineering of concrete structures
column10: Design of reinforced concrete buildings including concepts and code practices routinely used in professional structural engineering design for concrete members and structural systems. Behavior of building members as related to design will be discussed as well.

column9: Same as CEVE 431
column10: Instruction in testing and data analysis, design of concrete mix, casting concrete cylinders and reinforced concrete beams, fabrication of steel frame, testing of concrete beams and steel frame.

column9: Course objectives involve students learning "basic chemical transport models for river, lake, groundwater and atmospheric systems" and "source, fate and transport, and human health and ecological system impact of important environmental contaminants (including organic, inorganic and biological contaminants)". Expected course outcomes include the ability to "formulate environmental pollution problems by identifying sources, sinks and major mass transport processes in an environmental system" and "work as a team to analyze contaminant transport behaviors in an environmental system and communicate results" - helps us to better frame the sustainability challenge of environmental remediation
column10: Physical and chemical principles governing the fate and transport of contaminants in the aqueous environment, and the applications of such principles in environmental engineering. Emphasis is put on mass transport and transportation processes in natural and engineering systems. Previous course work in fluid mechanics and calculus through differential equations is strongly suggested.

column9: Syllabus has no notable focus on sustainabiity - rather, focused on the science and engineering of steel structures
column10: Design of structural steel buildings including concepts and material routinely used in professional structural engineering design practice for steel members, connections and assemblies. Behavior of building members as related to design will be discussed as well.

column9: Course objectives include "[a]n abaility to apply science and engineering concepts related to environmental microbiology and an understanding of: core central metabolic and respiratory pathways in bacteria and archaea; feasibility of biochemical reactions using equilibrium thermodynamic expressions; microbial processes and their role in biogeochemical cycles" and "[a]n ability to discuss the role of microbial communities in engineered systems and natural processes, and their impact on environmental and public health" - however, simply talking about applications to the environment does not imply that the course itself is oriented towards sustainability.
column10: Fundamentals of microbiology and the ecology of microbes, highlighting their interactions with each other and the environment, and integration of these principles in the context of important natural and engineered environmental systems.

column9: Although transportation systems are key to the future of sustainability, this course is not oriented towards sus challenges, but rather simply understanding how transport systems are planned and plotted.
column10: Survey of operation characteristics of transport modes the elements of transportation planning, and the design of stationary elements.

column9: Among the objectives of the coures: "to provide a foundation for design and protection of bridges in extreme events, with an emphasis on seismic and coastal threats" - sustainability of bridges and bridge design, but not actually oriented towards any specific sustainability challenges
column10: This course integrates information from various engineering and scientific disciplines to provide a rational basis for bridge design under regular and extreme loading. It provides an introduction to bridge engineering, including bridge systems, construction material, loading, and reliability-based design. Design, analysis, and retrofit for seismic and coastal threats will be introduced.

column9: More focused on engineering principles than their application to sus challenges
column10: Introduction to fundamentals of soil mechanics will include phase relationships, grain size, plasticity, soil classification, and clay mineralogy. The effect of water in soils, including capillarity, shrinkage and swelling, permeability, seepage and effective stress will be discussed. Consolidation, settlement, compressibility, failure theory, and the strength of sands and clays will be investigated. Design considerations will be discussed. Introduction to fundamentals of foundation engineering will include subsurface exploration methods and lateral earth pressures. The design of shallow and deep foundations, including pile installation and geophysical and geotechnical site investigation will be presented.

column9: Same as CEVE 471
column10: Determine the water content, liquid limit, plastic limit, grain size from sieve and hydrometer analyses, falling head permeability, specific gravity, and the shear strength of clays from pocket penetrometer, Torvane, miniature vane, unconsolidated undrained triaxial compression and direct shear tests. Study the consolidation of clays and the compaction of clays and sands.

column9: "THe movement of chemicals in the subsurface affecs health impacts to people and ecological receptors, the type of response needed, and the timeframe over which action needs to be taken... In the final project, students wil learn how to use groundwater flow and contaminant transport numerical models routinely used in the environmental industry". One of the ABET learning outcomes of the course is the "ability to apply engineering design to produce solutions tht meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors". The final project includes "design of groundwater remediation system." The class is not solely focused on sustainability, but is oriented in part towards how its main topic is relevant to sus challenges.
column10: Darcy's law, 1-D and 2-D steady-state groundwater flow, transient groundwater flow, aquifer testing, movement of chemicals in the subsurface, modeling groundwater flow and contaminant transport, current issues in hydrogeology including salt water intrusion, subsidence, and emerging environmental contaminants. Includes a final project using groundwater flow and contaminant transport models MODFLOW and MT3D.

column9: Assuming that these projects focus in some way on sustainability and sus challenges, so I am including them. It would be great to have some example information on past projects though, to justify my thinking more.
column10: The capstone designed course in the Spring Semester will provide senior engineering students with a complete designed experience including fundamental design issues in the major areas of the curriculum, small team experiences, project proposals, progress reports and presentations, design software and computations, major report writing, and a final presentation to the CEE faculty and an external jury of professional engineers. An established local firm will assist in teaching practical design methods and consultation with other faculty is required as part of the overall experience.

column9: See CEVE 480.
column10: Lectures will focus on various engineering design topics and CAD training. Potential design projects will be introduced and students will form interdisciplinary design teams. Design teams will present before jury to win their design projects.

column9: The focus of the course is on toxicity, superfund sites, and how thre EPA responds to thses things. Fundamentally about sustainability and addressing sus challenges
column10: Learn and apply quantitative risk assessment methodology to estimate human health risk from environmental exposure to contamination in air, soil and water. Students will conduct a series of team projects focused on toxicology, risk based screening levels, exposure concentration estimation and risk characterization.

column5: Modeling And Analysis Of Networked Systems
column9: Course description has no notable focus on sustainability or sus challenges
column10: This course introduces methods for modeling, characterizing and predicting the behavior of complex infrastructure and technological systems. The discussed analysis methods rely on network science optimization, and computational complexity principles so as to unravel the emergent features of structural and infrastructure systems. Topological properties, ranking tools, dynamic processes, and percolation-based resilience are studied from analytical, algorithmic, and numerical simulation perspectives. The course also explores interdependencies and mitigation actions for spatially and temporally evolving systems. The graduate level course includes advanced exercises in homework and exams, as well as a research-oriented final project.

column9: "Introduction to modeling and system identification of dynamic systems and structures to wind, wave and earthquake forces" - although there is an emphasis on natural disasters, it is not in a mindfully sustainable way and most of the class is focused purely on the modeling that allows better understanding of these systems in general.
column10: Introduction to modeling and system identification of dynamic systems with machine learning. Students in CEVE 596 will be required to do more advanced assignments and a project.

column9: No notable focus on sustainability from description, and the syllabus provides litttle to no detail on the course contents.
column10: Enrollment is open to all students. Undergraduate enrollment requires instructor permission via special registration form. An introduction to the basic principles of nanoscience and nanotechnology. Size dependent physical properties of nanoscopic solids will be described using solid state physics and molecular orbital theory as a foundation. Wet chemical techniques that produce nanoscale materials (e.g. carbon nanotubes, semiconductor and metallic nanocrystals, dendrimers...) will be introduced in the second half of the semester.

column5: Physical Chemical Proesses For Water Quality Control
column9: Course objectives inclue "introduce major water and wastewater treatment schemes" and "analyze future water technology needs". The term paper is titled "physical chemical processes for nutrient recovery in future urban water systems" - looking towards the future and more environmentally friendly water treatment practices - but at the same time, a large portion of the class is focused on hard science and not its applications, so this is not considered a "focus" class.
column10: Principles, modeling and design aspects of physical chemical treatment processes in drinking water, wastewater and groundwater remediation applications. Modern treatment technologies such as membrane separation, advanced oxidation, and photocatalysis will be covered.

column9: The course focuses much more on the fundamentals of water treatment than on solving problems or learning about sustainability in this arena.
column10: Theory and application of biochemical processes in environmental engineering.

column9: "Course will cover theory, applications to real environmental problems, the available public domain software, and needed numerical methods. At the successful completion of this course students will be able to estimate equilibrium, kinetic and transport properties of all low MWt organic chemicals in nearly any environment" . However, more focused on the fundamental science of accomplishing this than its relevance to sus challenges
column10: A course covering parameter estimation methods, thermodynamics, and kinetic needed to predict the fate, transports, and reactivity of organic compounds in air, water, and soils. Topics: volatization, solubility, sorption, partitioning, diffusion, aquatic reactivity, photochemistry, and transport modeling.

column9: The course is focused around the objective of ensuring that teachers are using best practices in the classroom. Less about sus challenges that the teachers may be talking about in the classroom.
column10: The Nano-Environmental Engineering for Teachers (NEET) course is designed to serve AP environmental science teachers. The purpose of the program is to increase the current knowledge of educators to empower them in implementing rigorous project-based engineering activities on the topic of water sustainability. Instructor Permission Required.

column9: Learning outcomes depend on student project, but include "an ability to a system component to meet desired needs within realistic constraints such as environmental, ethical, health and safety, practicality, and sustainability". However, because there is not enough detail on example projects provided, it is not clear that this is a reasonable focus or way in which the course orients itself.
column10: Professional master Project course involves the following (1) a project of practical relevance to the practice of Civil and Environmental Engineering, and (2) detailed project report. Students need to work with a faculty advisor.

column9: The weekly topics of the course are typically focused around sustainability topics: innovation ecosystems, global water issues, social aspects of new technology adoption, etc.Moreover, the course itself is focused on NEWT, which is itself a center at Rice that mainly focuses on sustainability in engineering and energy.
column10: This seminar will introduce NEWT graduate students to the basic scientific concepts behind NEWT research. It is also intended to develop a common language for NEWT students in different research areas, and to contribute to the development of a center culture.

column9: Description is not focused enough on sustainability to warrant inclusion.
column10: Formal lecture and assigned reading in topics such as redox kinetics and thermodynamics, absorption and desorption, and the associated mathematics. An advanced topics course.

column9: Applying concepts of engineering to the problems of sustainability
column10: Basic principles of Microbial Physiology, Metabolism, Stoichiometry, Thermodynamics and Kinetics applied to the selection, design and performance evaluation of engineered and intrinsic bioremediation systems.

column5: Advanced Topics In Environmental Engineering Sciences
column9: Not enough detail from description to justify inclusion
column10: Special topics in Graduate Study.

column9: Not enough detail from description to justify inclusion
column10: Advanced topics in Graduate Study.

column5: Advanced Topics In Environmental Biotechnology And Nanotechnology
column9: Not enough detail from description to justify inclusion
column10: Research oriented presentations and discussions of landmark papers and experimental methods for doctoral students in the Alvarez research group.

column5: Introduction To Chemical And Biomolecular Engineering
column9: Course addresses various sustainability challenges relevant to engineering, inculding "sustainable and affordable energy" and "developing production methods friendly to our environment"
column10: A series of lectures for freshman that outline how chemical and biomolecular engineers tackle today's major energy, health, environmental and economic challenges by working to provide sustainable and affordable energy, by designing new materials, biological products or medical therapeutics, and by developing production methods that are friendly to our environment.

column9: More focused on the lab techniques than on actual sustainability issues
column10: Fundamental chemical engineering experiments demonstrating laboratory safety procedures, use of analytical equipment, and basic fluid mechanics, phase behavior, energy and mass balances, and fluid properties. Lectures will introduce technical report writing and communication.

column9: Description makes it clear that the course is focused on sustainability - "students will work in teams to develop sustainable solutions" for energy related and environmental concerns
column10: Students will work in teams to develop sustainable solutions for energy or environmental problems affecting our Houston and Rice communities. Emphasis will be placed on the integration of engineering fundamentals with societal issues, environmental and safety considerations, sustainability and professional communications.

column9: Focused more on lab technique than on the application of it to sus challenges
column10: Experiments demonstrating principles presented in core chemical engineering courses.

column9: Course outcome: "The student completing this course will demonstrate an ability to apply engineering desing to produce solutions that meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors" - seems to be focused on problem solving towards sus challenges
column10: Examination of principles of chemical process safety through case studies and group discussions.

column9: Evaluating human impact on the environment and "how innovation information technologies can provide alternatives for sustainable growth"
column10: Topics in development and environmental economics focusing on how innovation can improve underdeveloped economies and our environment. Introduction to a general framework for assessing the impact of humans on the environment. Environmental consequences of increasing energy use. Case studies showing how innovation information technologies can provide alternatives for sustainable growth.

column9: The topics covered in the course are more focused on general design/engineering principles than their relevance to sustainability.
column10: Design principles as applied to chemical engineering systems. Engineering economic principles. Costs of equipment, feedstocks, and utilities. Equipment design. Use of modern simulation tools.

column9: One of the course outcomes is "an ability to apply engineering design to produce solutions that meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors" - however, it is not clearly stated whether design projects actually attempt to address sus challenges.
column10: Strategies for conceptual design of complex chemical engineering systems. Components include sustainability, heat and power integration, Students tackle engineering design projects in small groups.

column9: The decision making processes outlined in the syllabus are more focused on business/economics than on sus concerns.
column10: Use of concepts from economics, accounting, and finance in making design and operating decisions in the field of chemical engineering. Introduction to use of life-cycle analysis in decision-making.

column9: Not a notable focus on sustainability related topics
column10: Covers core principles, design considerations and empirical techniques required for biomolecular engineering workflows, control systems engineering for biological chassis including feedback and dynamic regulation, separations of biological molecules, and bioprocess engineering.

column9: Focused on technical skills rather than their applications to sus challenges.
column10: This course covers general separation principles by equilibrium, diffusion and convective mass transport. Topics covered mass transport, distillation, solid-liquid and liquid-liquid extraction, crystallization, absorption, adsorption, stripping and membrane processes.

column9: Not notably focused on sustainability
column10: This course is designed to understand how change and energy flow in basic semiconductor devices. First or second year graduate students from different disciplines and backgrounds will learn about fundamental concepts that describe the physics of semiconductors all the way from atoms and crystal structure to the workings of solar cells and light emitting diodes.

column5: Thermodynamic Applications For Energy And Environmental Systems
column9: Looking at energy use and its relationship to the environment - unclear whether it acddresses problems with fossil fuels (which seem to be the topic of the course).
column10: Review of fundamentals of phase and chemical equilibrium thermodynamics and electro-chemistry, and their applications to model the phase behavior of petroleum reservoir fluids, and the generation and transformation of energy from renewable resources. Modeling of the partitioning of contaminants in the environment, carbon capture and sequestration and other environmental applications.

column9: The objective of the course includes "an ability to recognize ethical and professional responsibilities in engineering situations and make informed judgements, which must consider the impact of engineering solutions in global, economic, environmental and societal contexts". however, the actual content of the class seems mch more focused on technical skill than problem solving.
column10: Experiments demonstrating principles presented in core chemical engineering courses including transport phenomena, thermodynamics, and process control professionalism and engineering ethics.

column5: Petroleum Phase Behavior And Flow Assurance
column9: Focuses on fossil fuels but not the problems associated with them
column10: Reviews fundamentals of phase and chemical equalibria thermodynamics focusing on the application of experimental and advanced modeling techniques to characterize reservoir fluids and predict their phase behavior and thermo-physical properties. Intended for students who wish to develop expertise on PVT modeling and gain understanding of common petroleum flow assurance problems.

column5: Two Phase Flow/Multiphase Flow In Pipes
column9: Focuses on fossil fuels but not the problems associated with them
column10: This course addresses the basics concepts, fundamentals, mathematical modeling and practical issues in multiphase fluid flow containing oil, water, gas and suspended solid particles in the oil and gas well columns, offshore and onshore production systems and pipelines. This course will have both an undergraduate and graduate level.

column9: Focused on fossil fuels but not the problems associated
column10: Modeling of dynamic processes. Response of uncontrolled systems. Transfer functions. Feedback controllers; response and stability of controlled systems; frequency response. Design of feedback controllers. Cascade, feed forward and multivariable control systems. Introduction to computer control. Use of simulators to design feedback controllers.

column9: Not notably sustainable based on syllabus
column10: An engineering design course focused on the design and fabrication of a car powered by a chemical reaction.

column9: Course is oriented around "applications [of electrochemistry] un renewable energy conversion technologies" - addressing sus challenge of ennergy
column10: This course involves electrochemistry fundamentals and their applications in renewable energy conversion technologies. Specific topics will include water splitting, fuel cells, CO2 reduction to fuels, Li ion batteries, flow batteries, and supercapacitors.

column9: One of the course objectives is "the relevance of energy systems in sustainable development." Topics covered include "Energy & Development Indexes. HDI - Human Development Index. EDI - Energy Development Index. SEDI - Sustainable Energy Development Index." and "Climate Change and Environmental Impact. Greenhosue effect & greenhouse gas emissions: biogenic & anthropogenic... Human link to climate change... Scenarios for future rates of Co2 emissions. Long-term effects of increasing average global temperature, current efforts to counteract climate change."" as well as characterizing various types of renewable eneryg.
column10: Application of energy conversion and the energy-environment-economy system. Energy Indexes and its correlation with energy supply and demand. The impact of energy consumption in health, income and education. Environmental policy, climate change and the impact of energy systems. Present and projected supply and demand of energy from primary sources, renewables and non-renewables. Hydroelectric, Thermoelectric power generation, from Hydrogen, Nuclear, Solar, Wind, and biomass.

column9: "Application of energy conversion and the energy-environment-economy system. Present and projected supply and demand of energy." "This course is designed to teach students the principles and applications of energy conversion and its utilization, including energy sources, energy consumption, fossil fuels for thermal power generation, thermo-nuclear power, solar energy, hydropower, wind energy, geothermal power, hydrogen energy, and the related environmental and economic matters. The impact of energy consumption in health, income and education" Topics covered include "climate change and environmental impact" along with specific renewable energy sources.
column10: This course will give an overview of various unconventional and renewable energy resources and technical challenges facing their production and usage. Issues around energy security, sustainability and affordability will be addressed. In addition, the role of disruptive innovations on energy systems will be discussed. The student will develop both a global and regional view on energy production.

column5: Discovery And Engineering Of Bioactive Natural Products
column9: More focused on fundamentals of small-scale biocatalysis than its applications/impacts
column10: The course surveys the discovery and biosynthesis of natural products and engineering approaches to modify and optimize production of natural products. Topics include: Mechanistic enzymology. Biosynthetic gene clusters and pathways. Bioinformatic analysis and genome mining. Engineering of enzymes for biocatalysis. Metabolic engineering for natural and non-natural products.

column9: Focuses on fossil fuels but not the problems associated with them
column10: This course covers industrial applications of catalysis and petrochemical processes. It intends to bridge the gap between the fundamentals and theories of heterogeneous catalysis and the practical applications in petrochemical industries. It is suitable for graduate students and advanced undergraduate students with permission.

column5: Flow And Transport Through Porous Media I
column9: More focused on fundamental science, not its application to sus challenges
column10: Study of the geology, chemistry, and physics of multicomponent, multiphase fluids in porous media. Includes hydrostatic and hydrodynamic properties of fluids in soils and rocks and the simulation of fundamental transport processes in one dimension.

column5: Oil And Gas Asset Integrity I
column9: Focuses on fossil fuels but not the problems associated with them
column10: The course integrates risk assessment and mitigation, asset integrity management, corrosion control and materials selection across the oil and gas value chain, from production to refining and retail. The full course covers 2 semesters. Session "I,” to be delivered in the Spring 2017 semester. Session "II" will be delivered in the Fall 2017 semester.

column5: Thermodynamics And Applications To Oil Production
column9: Focuses on fossil fuels but not the problems associated with them
column10: Students will learn how thermodynamics can be used to gain insights into hydrocarbon energy production processes. Classical thermo is covered in bulk phase equilibrium and stability, interfaces, and then liquid films areas. Some statistical themo and molecular simulations. Effect of nano-size and charge on material properties, nucleation, species distribution, climate change, and shale gas/oil.

column5: Oil And Gas Asset Integrity Ii
column9: Focuses on fossil fuels but not the problems associated with them
column10: The course integrates risk assessment and mitigation, asset integrity management, corrosion control and materials selection across the oil and gas value chain, from production to refining and retail. The full course covers 2 semesters. Session "I,” to be delivered in the Spring 2017 semester. Session "II" will be delivered in the Fall 2017 semester.

column9: The applications section of the description for the course touches on sustainability challenges and themes, but not enough to warrant inclusion.
column10: Principles of metabolic engineering: overview of biochemical pathways; kinetics and thermodynamics of metabolic networks; genetic engineering and molecular biology tools; metabolic flux analysis using stoichiometric and labeling techniques; metabolic control analysis. Metabolic engineering in the postgenomic era: functional genomics and systems biology. Emerging applications: chemicals from biorenewables; food ingredients; health and disease.

column9: Focus of the course is providing a classical foundation in thermo, not applying.
column10: Bulk-Phase Equilibrium and Irreversibility, and Interfacial Thermodynamics of fluids and elastic materials are presented in a unified framework. Thermodynamic stability of fluids and elastic solids are also covered. Examples include past climates changes, various diffusion processes, and size effect on properties.

column9: Focuses on fundamentals, not on applications to sus challenges
column10: Calculation of multicomponent-multiphase transport in one to three dimensions using finite difference methods. Includes development of multidimensional models of systems and representation and estimation of geological heterogeneity.

column9: More focused on the science than its application/relevance to sus challenges
column10: Introduction to concepts necessary for application of systems - Biology Approaches to Human Diseases. Topics include transcriptional and metabolic design principles, introduction to various regulatory network motifs in diseases and potential treatments using embryonic stem cells. Analysis of complex diseases using engineering concepts such as optimality, nonequilibrium thermodynamics, multiscale analysis and spatiotemporal transport.

column9: Focused on fundamental lab skills, not application to sus challenges
column10: This course is for rising junior and senior high school students. As visiting students, the students will conduct scientific research in the laboratories of Rice faculty in the areas of Nanotechnology, Chemistry, Materials, and Engineering. Two applications need to be submitted for enrollment into this course.

column9: Focused on "how to join a lab" not on applying lab work to sus challenges
column10: This half-semester course introduces freshmen to chemical research at Rice and in Houston

column9: Focused on fundamental knowledeg, not application of chemistry to sustainability
column10: Introduction of chemical phenomena emphasizing problems and methods in Chemistry. Either CHEM 121 or CHEM 151 may be taken as a prerequisite for higher study in chemistry, but only one of these may be taken for credit. Students must also register for CHEM 123 General Chemistry Laboratory I. The course and the co-requisite lab are graded jointly.

column9: Focused on fundamental knowledeg, not application of chemistry to sustainability
column10: A continuation of CHEM 121.

column9: Focused on fundamental knowledeg, not application of chemistry to sustainability
column10: An accelerated introduction to chemical phenomena emphasizing principles and theories in chemistry. Recommended strongly for students who plan to major in chemistry or have a strong high school background. Students with AP credit in Chemistry who intend to pursue advanced study in Chemistry are strongly encouraged to take CHEM 151 and CHEM 152.

column9: Focused on fundamental knowledeg, not application of chemistry to sustainability
column10: A continuation of CHEM 151.

column9: Focused on chemistry of art, not sustainability of conservation techniques
column10: The chemistry of the materials and methods used to create, conserve and authenticate art objects will be presented. Topics will include sculpture, painting, photography, textiles, jewelry, furniture, etc. Taught in conjunction with the Conservation Department and Staff of the MFAH.

column9: No notable emphasis on sus challenges or topics on syllabus.
column10: This course examines the chemistry involved in the composition, transformation, and consumption of food. Topics include chemical properties and reactions of food, cooking tools, and techniques, sensory perception, and nutrition. Lectures and hands-on kitchen experiments are taught in conjunction with Rice Dining Service. Knowledge of high school chemistry is expected.

column9: Focused on fundamental knowledeg, not application of chemistry to sustainability
column10: CHEM 201 is a one-semester lecture course intended for 1st-year undergraduate prospective Chemistry majors who have received credit for AP Chemistry (or equivalent). It is strongly encouraged for those who will take upper-level chemistry courses as a means to refresh and deepen their understanding of challenging core topics. Focus areas include: quantum descriptions of atoms and molecules, chemical thermodynamics, equilibria, and reaction kinetics.

column9: No notable focus on sus challenges and their relevance to lab work
column10: Synthesis, purification, and characterization of organic compounds.

column9: No notable focus on sus challenges and their relevance to lab work
column10: Organic laboratory designed for chemical engineering majors. Emphasis placed on the synthesis and the characterization of organic compounds.

column9: No notable focus of seminars on sustainability related topics
column10: An introduction to modern chemical research through seminars and/or directed reading.

column9: "Applications of analytical chemistry to areas of medicine, forensics, environment, and materials will be explored" - notably, though, it is unclear how much time is actually focused on these applications.
column10: A treatment of modern analytical chemistry with an emphasis on instrumentation. Applications of analytical chemistry as applied to areas of medicine, forensics, and material.

column9: Focused more on foundational knowledge of inorganics than their relevance to sus challenges
column10: Survey of the periodic table; atomic and molecular structure; bonding in covalent, ionic, and electron deficient systems; thermochemical principles and experimental techniques for analysis, structure determination, and synthesis.

column9: No notable emphasis on sus challenges or topics in course description.
column10: Advanced techniques in inorganic and organometallic synthesis will be covered including air sensitive manipulations using Schlenk line, vacuum lines and dry box.

column9: Focused on fossil fuels but not the problems associated
column10: Survey of the range of key industrial chemical processes to understand the application of industrial chemistry, catalysis, reactor design, and other chemical engineering technologies in the development of those processes. Appropriate for juniors and higher.

column9: More focused on foundational skills of proposal writing rather than sustainability
column10: This course teaches how to prepare scientific proposals including developing an idea, writing, and peer review including creating a mock panel review.

column9: No notable focus on sustainability from description, and the syllabus provides litttle to no detail on the course contents.
column10: Enrollment is open to all students. Undergraduate enrollment requires instructor permission via special registration form. An introduction to the basic principles of nanoscience and nanotechnology. Size dependent physical properties of nanoscopic solids will be described using solid state physics and molecular orbital theory as a foundation. Wet chemical techniques that produce nanoscale materials (e.g. carbon nanotubes, semiconductor and metallic nanocrystals, dendrimers...) will be introduced in the second half of the semester.

column4: Taught in Spring 2022, but syllabus links incorrectly
column9: No notable emphsis or angle of sustainability in the course descriptions
column10: This course will expand on our learned knowledge of some of the Nature's most intriguing molecules and the ability of Man to discover, synthesize, modify and use them to our advantage in what areas were not formerly envisioned.

column9: Focused on the science of drug discovery rather than the applications of it to situations of health inequality
column10: An introductory course intended to provide the student with an overview of the elements of drug discover, design and development. Targets for drug discovery will be discussed, as well as considerations of drug optimization with respect to the biological target and drug metabolism. A summary of the FDA and patent processes will also be included.

column9: Focused more on fundamental science of biochemistry than its sustainability applications
column10: This course examines biological problems from a chemical perspective. Starting with the structural and functional properties of amino acids, nucleotides, and sugars, we discuss how these molecules organize into higher-order structures (e.g., proteins and nucleic acids). Topics include macromolecular structure-function relationships, developing hybrid chemical/biological drugs, and modern target discovery approaches.

column9: Focused on the science of drug discovery rather than the applications of it to situations of health inequality
column10: Drug discovery requires a close integration of chemistry and biology. This course explores the design and development of new medicine from a chemical biological perspective. Topics includes fundamental methods for biomolecule synthesis and engineering and application to hybrid chemical/biologic drugs, as well as modern approaches for target discovery and validation.

column9: Although applications of carbon nanostructures are mentioned in the syllabus, it is not clear if/how much these applications focus towards sus challenges.
column10: This course will survey the chemistry, physics, and selected applications of carbon nanostructures. Fullerenes, carbon nanotubes, and graphene will be the main focus. Students are expected to have a solid background in physical chemistry.

column9: No notable mention of sustainability and its challenges in the course description.
column10: Selected topics in modern chemical biology. The development and application of chemical methods to probe, perturb, and understand biological systems. Topics include protein and DNA chemistry, classical and modern approaches to inhibitor development, and chemical reaction design in living cells.

column9: Centered around language acquisition and development language skills, but does not talk about sustainability topics.
column10: Development of interactional competence in Chinese (sociolinguistic and sociocultural knowledge) to communicate and interact with speakers of Chinese. The course is based on a student-centered, critical-thinking approach to language analysis/acquisition. No prior knowledge of this language is necessary.
column11: Center For Language And Interpersonal Communication

column9: Centered around language acquisition and development language skills, but does not talk about sustainability topics.
column10: Continuation of CHIN 141, for students whose home language is not Chinese. Development of interactional competence in Chinese, (sociolinguistic and sociocultural knowledge) to communicate and interact with speakers of Chinese. The course is based on a student-centered, critical-thinking approach to language analysis/acquisition.
column11: Center For Language And Interpersonal Communication

column5: Accelerated Second Year Chinese For Heritage Learners
column9: Centered around language acquisition and development language skills, but does not talk about sustainability topics.
column10: Intensive second-year Chinese course for students with an intermediate level in spoken Chinese who lack knowledge of Chinese characters. This course covers the equivalents of CHIN 263 and 264 with a greater emphasis on reading and writing. Students will be prepared for CHIN 301 or 311 upon completion of the course. Mutually Exclusive: Credit cannot be earned for this course AND CHIN 263 and/or CHIN 264. CHIN 206 covers the same material as 263 and 264 combined.

column10: Continuation of CHIN 142, for students whose home language is not Chinese. Development of interactional competence in Chinese, (sociolinguistic and sociocultural knowledge) to communicate and interact with speakers of Chinese. The course is based on a student-centered, critical-thinking approach to language analysis/acquisition.

Development of interactional competence in Chinese (sociolinguistic and sociocultural knowledge) to communicate and interact with speakers of Chinese. The course is based on a student-centered, critical-thinking approach to language analysis/acquisition.

column9: Centered around language acquisition and development language skills, but does not talk about sustainability topics.

Emphasis on developing reading and writing ability as more authentic materials and socio-cultural topics are introduced. Upon completion students are expected to be able to write approximately 650 characters and be able to perform communicative tasks appropriate to this range of tasks

Upon completion, students expected to be able to write approximately 800 characters and perform communicative tasks appropriate to this range of characters.

column9: Centered around language acquisition and development language skills, but does not talk about sustainability topics.

Writing assignments stress skills necessary for basic personal needs and tasks necessary for writing social correspondence. At the completion of 311, students will be able to write approximately 800 Chinese characters, and be able to perform communicative tasks appropriate to this range of characters.
column11: Center For Language And Interpersonal Communication

column9: Centered around language acquisition and development language skills, but does not talk about sustainability topics.
column10: This course helps students develop an advanced level of proficiency in Chinese through the analysis and use of the target language in the context of specific topics of interest that will vary
column11: Center For Language And Interpersonal Communication

column9: Deals with traditional chinese tales in the historical sense and how people are viewed in chinese literature, but does not tackle the core problems of sustainability.
column10: Learning Chinese literature and culture through reading vernacular stories, fantastic tales, biographies, and philosophical parables. Discussion topics: literature and Confucianism, Taoism and Buddhism; literature and history; self and other; fantastic world and reality; women as domestic aliens and aliens portrayed as women, etc. Readings are in English translation.
column11: Center For Language And Interpersonal Communication

column9: "Topics include: China’s modernity and the formation and cinematic visualization of modern Chinese literature; self, state, and nation; sex, gender, and power; connections between China’s past and present, etc." - the course will help students "overcome their originally orientalist, occidentalist, or any kind of chauvinistic and centralist perspectives, in order for them to view the world from a humanitarian position, especially on behalf of marginalized groups of people and beings." - this frame shifting feels important based on the sustainbility challenges.
column10: Exploration of modern Chinese literature through the visual imagery of Chinese films to show how and why different time periods and different media affect the theme of a story. One third covers movie adaptations of classical Chinese literature. Films subtitled in English, shown outside of class. All readings in English translation.

column9: Not convinced after reading syllabus - less "zoomed out" and more focused on the content of the Tales
column10: Learning Chinese literature and culture through reading vernacular stories, fantastic tales, biographies, and philosophical parables. Discussion topics: literature and Confucianism, Taoism and Buddhism; literature and history; self and other; fantastic world and reality; women as domestic aliens and aliens portrayed as women, etc. Readings are in English translation.

column9: Contains a similar note in learning objectives to ASIA 332. "The course will also help them overcome their originally orientalist, occidental, or any kind of centralist perspectives, in order for them to view the world from a humanitarian position, especially on behalf of marginalized groups of peoples and beings." But this is more classical and historical in nature rather than contemporary or forward looking
column10: Examination of the basic characteristics of classical Chinese novels, primarily through six important works from the 16th to 18th centuries: Water Margin, Monkey, Golden Lotus, Scholars, Romance of the Three Kingdoms, and Dream of the Red Chamber. All readings in English translation.

column9: Students read a variety of social, political and economic issues, which are core issues of sustainability as outlined by the Earth Charter.
column10: Continuation of CHIN 302, emphasis on developing oral fluency at the discourse level and cultivating advanced writing skill. Students will read and discuss a variety of social, political and economic issues. Upon completion, students are expected to be able to write approx. 1000 characters.
column11: Center For Language And Interpersonal Communication

column9: Centered around language acquisition and development language skills, but does not talk about sustainability topics.
column10: Continuation of CHIN 401, emphasis on strengthening speaking and writing skills at the advance level with more authentic readings selected from newspapers, literary works and academic texts. Upon completion, students are expected to be able to write approx. 1200 characters
column11: Center For Language And Interpersonal Communication

column5: The Original Beauty Of Chinese Literature
column9: Nothing in this course pertains to sustainability topics.
column10: The course will expose students to the best classical literary works created in the Chinese tradition, and give them a general introduction to different genres, including poetry, fiction, drama, and philosophical essays. While the course is taught in English, all the readings will be in original texts of Chinese literature so that students will be able to taste its original beauty.
column11: Center For Language And Interpersonal Communication

column9: a "survey of Greek literature, thought, and culture" - not very forward-looking, and no explicit mentions of sus challenges
column10: An examination of the literary, artistic, and intellectual achievements of classical Greek civilization from Homer through the golden age of classical Athens to the spread of Greek culture in the Hellenistic world. The influence of ancient Greece on Western culture will be a focus. Case studies in the later reception of classical Greek literature (e.g., tragedy), philosophy (e.g., Socrates), history (e.g., democracy), and art (e.g., The Parthenon) will be examined.

column9: Although there is a discussion of Rome's legacy, the majority of the class is a historical and cultural survey. Moreover, the "legacy" in question is not oriented towards sustainability in any notable way.
column10: This course will investigate central aspects of Roman civilization: politics, religion, law, oratory, private life, public entertainment, literature, and visual art and architecture. We will also examine the place of ancient Rome in the western imagination, and the influence of ancient Rome on later politics, literature, and art.

column9: More focused on the key topics of Greek culture and literature than any theories or applications.
column10: We will read and analyze some of the most influential Greek myths (including their parallels and permutations in other cultures). Employing insights from a variety of theoretical approaches to myth, we will identify typical story patterns, characters, and events, and the values, anxieties, and aspirations for which they stand.

column9: More focused on providing a solid foundation in the genre than any theories or applications
column10: We will read 16 Greek tragedies by Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides as well as contemporary criticism of tragedy by Aristophanes, Plato, and Aristotle. We will consider how ancient tragedies were staged, how they were received by their audiences, how they fit in the life of Athens, how they influenced later dramatic arts, and how they continue to stimulate thinking about the human situation.

column9: More philosophical and cultural in nature than concerned with sus challenges, based on the description
column10: Ancients and moderns have participated in constant dialogue – sometimes friendly, sometimes hostile – that still shapes the complexities of our own approaches to the past. This seminar traces approximately two millennia of conflict and compromise between so-called “ancients” and “moderns” from ancient Greece and Rome to the French Revolution and beyond.

column9: More focused on culture and art than its relevance to sustainability.
column10: This course explores the roots of the art and architecture of ancient Rome (ca. 600-200 BCE). In it we will examine the earliest vestiges of sculpture, painting and architecture from the Archaic and Classical periods to the twisted forms of Hellenistic conquest. You will grapple with the questions of cultural agency, connoisseurship, cultural interaction, network and object theories and spatial imagination to question standard narratives that divide Rome in this time from neighboring Greek polities.

column9: No clear interest in environment or sustainability from course description.
column10: "Architectural Revolution" has been tied to Le Corbusier, the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre, Brunelleschi and to towering Gothic cathedrals. At the foundation of all these endeavors is the Concrete Revolution in Roman Architecture. In this course we'll look at the four essential elements of this revolution from the fourth century BCE to the fifth century CE, and we'll investigate how shifts in application and experience created a background that informs design to this day.

column9:
Talks about what it means to become Intercultural Competent, as well as navigate
the nuances of our and others’ identities, alongside race, class, and stereotypes
in US.
column10: This course centers on the development of intercultural communicative competence in the context of learning a L2 with special focus on language uses, sociolinguistic strategies and structures of interactional discourses in spoken and written languages.
column11: Center For Language And Interpersonal Communication

column5: History Of Cinema And Media I
column9: Although the course "familiarizes students with the socio-political and cultural contexts in which these works originated and to which they responded," it is not really focused on these contexts or the social issues they are implicated in
column10: This seminar will introduce students to the history of cinema from its inception to 1945 by considering individual cinematic artifacts in their technological, economic, aesthetic, political, and social contexts.

column5: History Of Cinema And Media Ii
column9: "A broad spetrum of issues will be discussed, including cinema's engagement with politics and ideology; theories of spectatorship; cinematic time and space; emotion, identification, and distance; genre and authorship; gender, sexuality, and the body; and the ethics of moving images" - but any discussion of social issues (adjacent to sus challenges) is solely in the context of the films themselves.
column10: Introduction to major movements, practices and theories of film and media from 1945 to present.

column9: Applications of synthetic biology listed in the course description are related to sus challenges of health and environmental equity.
column10: Synthetic biology is a mixture of engineering and biology which emphasizes applications to the real world. Whether it be using artificial, small bacteria to clean water, genetically engineering crops to resist harsh climates, or even creating medicine through the help of microorganisms, all these actions are examples of synthetic biology being put to use. How can we use synthetic biology to engineer biological specimen for the sake of fixing real world problems that affect humanity? Students will tackle this question by analyzing real world problems and evaluating how/whether synthetic biology can be used to solve such problems. Students will use their understanding of synthetic biology to pick a problem they are passionate about and go on to develop and design a solution using synthetic biology. Solutions can range from innovative mechanisms of disease detection, water filtration, material/fuel creation, and more. No prior knowledge of biology is necessary and students of all majors are welcome. Students will learn cellular processes crucial to synthetic biology, genetic circuit design, the scope of synthetic biology applications, and synthetic biology project design. In class, students will learn through activities/discussion, assigned reading/homework, and a project design stage with guidance from people of numerous biological backgrounds.

column9: "A critical portion of the course will investigate the forms that social justice takes in the 'real world' versus online" - looking critically at technology, social movements, social change, and development
column10: How much time do you spend online and how does that compare to your time offline? How do these different experiences mesh to influence the type of person you are? What kind of person does existing in these two planes make you? Hybrid Beings: Multiple Selves investigates the impacts of technology on our conceptions of self and embodied experience; focusing on visual technologies like print and screens. This course will focus predominantly on 21st century technologies, particularly the impact of social media on the way we conduct our lives and the ramifications of the corporate control of social life. A critical portion of the course will investigate the forms that social justice takes in the "real world" versus online; echo chambers, politically charged "news" generated by extremist groups, and the facilitation of these negative outcomes via the anonymity and lack of accountability afforded by the internet. Through our meanderings we will discuss ideas pertaining to materiality turn, phenomenology, power, gender, sexuality, race, intersectionality, and the social construction of experience. The ultimate question we pose is: What does it mean to BE in the 21st century and how can we adjust our behaviors to adapt to the inevitability of technology's growing guidance of our lives?

column9: Course is focused not only on understanding disabilities, but contfonting ableism and teaching students to be inclusive of people with disabilities. Course objectives include to "examine the biggest challenges the disabled community faces in our society" and "create an environment that allow those with disabilities/disorders to shine and show their talents".
column10: Explore various disabilities and mental disorders, with an emphasis on integration and acceptance.

column9: Emphasis on indigenous peoples and learning their history.
column10: This course provides a basic overview of Hawaiian history and culture. Students will learn to appreciate Hawai'i beyond its superficial beauty by investigating topics such as mythology, western contact, statehood, food, and more.

column9: Consumption is deeply tied to sus challenges related to waste and climate.
column10: This is an introduction to ethical, conscious lifestyles through the lens of social and ethical issues and how individuals interact with them in their everyday, 21st-century lives. Assignments ask students to question what issues they care about and how what they buy affects what they support.

column9: Not notably relating to sus challenges/topics.
column10: For Black men, what good are essays? This course explores the writerly activism, historical imagination, and the consequence of some of the best known work of W.E.B. Du Bois, James Baldwin, and several of their 21st century heirs. Taking cues from the subjects of the course, students will also get ample practice using the essay as a way to describe, analyze, and affect the contemporary black male condition. Permission of Instructor required. Instructor Permission Required.

column9: Considers sustainability challenges related to mass incarceration and "the efforts of a growing number of women and men committed to addressing the kinds of stark injustices that have proceeded from the nation's relatively recent and nearly insatiable impetus to criminalize and cage extraordinarily large numbers of its poor, non-white population"
column10: A course about the origins of mass incarceration in the United States; about the consequences of the present carceral state; and about efforts to address injustices that have proceeded from the nation’s relatively recent and nearly insatiable impetus to cage its poor, non-white population.

column9: More focused on politics in general than the politics that is relevant to sus challenges, based on description.
column10: Young Americans today are drawn to service-just not to public service. When so many people shrink from (or are repelled by) "politics" and "politicians", there has never been a better time to seek and exert leadership at every level. "Real Leaders, Real People" will draw practical lessons from the lives of leaders who overcame obstacles of various kinds.

column9: Relates heavily to migration and movement, whith is tied to sus challenges.
column10: President Trump swept to power on a promise to “Build a Wall” and to deport the undocumented, and these promises and their fulfillment have dominated media and political attention for several years. The border is in “crisis,” the United States in a “state of emergency.” Taught by a civil rights lawyer, this course surveys the real and imagined elements of this crisis: patterns of and responses to contemporary migration, border enforcement and the militarization of border communities, the promises and failures of immigration courts and immigrant detention, and the goals, costs and efficacy of a border wall.

column9: More focused on historical scholarship related to WMR and his role in the slave trade than putting that in context of current sus challenges related to race, class, education
column10: This seminar will meet every other week and will enable students to engage in original historical research about William Marsh Rice and his world, with a specific focus on slavery and its aftermath in Texas. The research will aid the work of the Task Force on Slavery, Segregation, and Racial Injustice.

column9: "This class is especially interested in Rice's black past. But this focus on the past also means that the class maintains a particular purchase on imagining the universit's black future, and analyzing Rice's black present."
column10: What does it mean, and what has it meant to be black at Rice? This seminar is focused on documenting and recovering the experience of black staff, students, and faculty at the university. The class is associated with the work of the Task Force on Slavery, Segregation, and Racial Injustice.

column5: Introduction To Academic Reading And Writing For International Graduate Students
column9: Centered around developing writing and language skills, but does not talk about sustainability topics.
column10: This course teaches fundamental academic reading and writing skills to international graduate students in the first two years of their studies. Students will learn how scholars construct arguments and use evidence to support claims, and they will practice writing texts that are relevant to their own courses and careers.

column5: Oral Communication Skills For International Graduate Students
column9: Centered around language acquisition and development language skills, but does not talk about sustainability topics.
column10: This course provides students with strategies to improve oral communication skills necessary for academic and professional success in North American contexts. Students will learn how to overcome common and individual challenges related to pronunciation clarity, small group interactions, and formal presentations. Final projects will be related to students' studies or research.

column5: Advanced Academic Writing For International Graduate Students
column9: This course is centered around developing writing skills and academic skills, but not around sustainability topics.
column10: This course addresses writing at both the macro- and micro- level, engaging students in such academic writing tasks as critiquing, reporting, and interpreting research findings, illustrating and justifying the significance of research, while also attending to mechanical topics. Writing assignments in the course will be linked to students' studies, courses, or research.

column9: Mention of ecology is not sufficeint to justify inclusion.
column10: An introduction to computation taught by solving real-world problems in architecture, statistics, linguistics, social networks, visual pattern recognition, and the simulation of complex systems in ecology. Technical topics include how to model computational artifacts operating in the world, how to design and implement algorithmic solutions in Python, and how to experimentally test and evaluate computational systems.

column9: Based on the description, the course adresses the sus challenge of technology, but not necessarily tied specifically to the environment.
column10: We will review the remarkable technology of the Information Age and examine its effects on the ways in which we live, work and think about the world around us. We will consider, for example, how the pervasive use of computers and networks is changing our ideas about property, privacy, authority, social relations, knowledge and identity. And we will discuss what further changes we might see as technology continues to advance.

column9: "students will master fundamentals of moral philosophy and principles of social responsibility; they will apply these modes of reflection and reasoning to current issues in computer science. These include but are not limited to algorithmic fairness and decision-making; surveillance and privacy; biased data and machine-learning outcomes; autonomous systems and human casualties; and diversity and inclusion in the tech industry" - adopting responsibility for the ethics of technology (violence, environment, and tech development) - however, not as focused on studying those challenges as sus challenges
column10: Given their growing power in the twenty-first century, computer scientists have duties both to society and their own profession to wield that power wisely and responsibly. In this discussion-and reflection-oriented course students will apply fundamentals of moral philosophy and social responsibility to current issues in computer science.

column9: More focused on monitoring infectious disease outbreaks than on how doing so can relate to sus challenges i.e. health inequities
column10: We will review, critique, and discuss computational methods and approaches for microbial forensics and infectious disease monitoring in the genomics era. The seminar will be divided into topic-specific sessions, focusing on emerging research trends and open challenges in the field.

column9: Focused on democracy and challenges to democracy in the context of elections - does this count as a sustainability challenge?
column10: This multidisciplinary course will consider how elections are conducted to enhance participation, to accurately measure the will of the electorate, and to be sufficiently rigorous to convince all parties that the results are legitimate. This course will consider the design and evaluation of election technologies, ranging from voter registration through the polling booth and vote tabulation. This course will consider three questions: how do individual voters interact with the voting technology, how are voting technologies engineered to be accurate and secure, and how do the social aspects of voting fulfill democratic goals for elections? A central requirement for this course will be group research projects, many operating in our community, built around the November election.

column9: No clear application to sustainability is evidenced in the description of the course
column10: Learning from large dataset is becoming a ubiquitous phenomena in all applications spanning robotics, medical decisions, internet, communication, biology, etc. Designed to give senior UG students a thorough grounding in the theory and algorithms needed for research and practical applications in machine learning for modern massive datasets. Topics draw from machine learning, classical statistics, algorithms and information theory

column9: More focused on the fundamentals of algorithmic robotics than their applications, althought hese applications (and their relevance to sus challenges) are mentioned on the syllabus
column10: Robots have fascinated people for generations. Today, robots are built for applications as diverse as exploring remote planets, de-mining war zones, cleaning toxic waste, assembling cars, inspecting pipes in industrial plants and mowing lawns. Robots are also interacting with humans in a variety of ways: robots are museum guides, robots assist surgeon sin life threatening operations, and robotic cars can drive us around. The field of robotics studies not only the design of new mechanisms but also the development of artificial intelligence frameworks to make these mechanism useful in the physical world, integrating computer science, engineering, mathematics and more recently biology and sociology, in a unique way. This class will present fundamental algorithmic advances that enable today’s robots to move in real environments and plan their actions. It will also explore fundamentals of the field of Artificial Intelligence through the prism of robotics. The class involves a significant programming project.

column9: No notable focus on sus challenges evident in description.
column10: This course is an introduction to cyber-physical systems, engineering artifacts in which computational components interact with and typically control physical components. Some common examples of cyber-physical systems include robots, Segways and lane-departure warning, LDW, systems in automobiles.

column9: No notable focus on sus challenges
column10: The course emphasizes the security of small embedded devices that are central to the Internet of Things (IoT) Era. We discuss the practical security attacks, challenges, constraints, and opportunities that arise in the IoT domain. Covered topics include security engineering, real world attacks, practical and side channel attacks, and hands-on lab/projects.

column9: Although the course description emphasizes that students will learn how biological network analysis can be used for downstream applications, the syllabus does not provide clarirty as to what those applications are enough for it to be said that they are sustainability related.
column10: This course covers computational aspects of biological network analysis, a major theme in the area of systems biology. The course discusses protein-protein interaction, signaling, metabolic, and functional networks, and covers issues related to constructing, analyzing various types of networks, as well as how they can be used for downstream applications

column9: "The course objective is to introduce students to the different subfields of biometical informatics, methodologies used, and professional choices available. The course outcomes are: to identify what is biomedical informatics, what are its main subfields, what research is encompassed in each of them, what are the methodologies used, and what are the different professional settings in which biomedical informatics is practiced" - focused on fundamentals, not on applying them to sus challenges
column10: This seminar introduces pre- and postdoctoral students in biomedical informatics to topics relevant to professional development in the discipline, which is no longer concentrated in labs as it was in its early days, but is now important in hospitals, outpatient clinics, companies and even the community. In these settings, researchers and practitioners are likely to encounter not only difficult technical challenges, but vexing problems of organizational change and development as well. We will consider some of these challenges, drawing on the insights of experts in psychology, organizational change, management and communications along with industry representatives and entrepreneurs. The seminar mixes lectures and readings with group and individual exercises.

column9: Focus on ethics, but not necessarily as they relate to sus challenges/sustainability in general.
column10: Given their growing power in the twenty-first century, data scientists have duties both to society and their own profession to wield that power wisely and responsibly. In this discussion-and reflection-oriented course students will apply fundamentals of moral philosophy and social responsibility to current issues in data science.

column9: Addresses evolving technology, but no notable emphasis on its application to sus challenges.
column10: This course provides a survey of autonomous robotic manipulation systems. In particular, we are interested in the most influential recent research, as well as the necessary fundamental concepts that have paved the roads. By reading relevant papers from top journals and conferences, we will discuss problems including grasping, motion planning, prehensile and non-prehensile manipulation, affordance and task modeling, hand design, and perception. Centered around the recent rapid development of various sensor technology, we will try to bridge the gaps between sensing modalities to each of the major problems in manipulation, with an emphasis on understanding how sensing modalities interact with other components in the system. Upon the completion of this course, students should have gained a comprehensive understanding of robotic manipulation as a research field, and should be able to define, formulate and analyze relevant scientific problems on a research level.

column9: Because cognitive science is such an interdisciplinary field, it could include sustainability-focused projects.
column10: Cognitive science is a basic science of mental operations in humans, animals, and artificial systems. It is a highly interdisciplinary endeavor that draws on philosophy, psychology, biology, linguistics, and computer science, among other traditional disciplines. This course provides an integrated introduction to the primary empirical methods for studying the human mind. Students will learn how the scientific method is applied to study mental information representation, manipulation, and utilization in natural and artificial cognitive systems. It will teach students to understand and evaluate existing methodological approaches as well as recognize what is necessary to replicate results. Topics include the philosophical foundations of cognitive science, basic methods of cognitive psychology, neuroscience, linguistics, computational modeling, data analysis, and ethical responsibility when conducting cognitive research.

column9: No indication of sustainability component.
column10: Supervised research on topics relevant to the cognitive sciences. Limited to majors in Cognitive Sciences

column9: No indication of sustainability component.
column10: Topics and credit hours vary each semester. Contact department for current semester topic(s). Repeatable for Credit.

column9: No indication of sustainability component.
column10: Independent directed research toward preparation of an undergraduate honors project or thesis. Repeatable for Credit.

column9: This course talks about solving real data science problems, which could include sustainability topics as outlined by the earth charter.
column10: In this course, students learn the fundamentals of data science and Python programming while working on teams to solve real data science challenges, design a data science pipeline, and derive and communicate valuable insights from data. This is a non-calculus based course with no prior background in statistics or programming required.

column5: Probability And Statistics For Data Science
column9: No indication of sustainability component.
column10: An introduction to mathematical statistics and computation for applications to data science. Topics include probability, random variables expectation, sampling distributions, estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and regression. A weekly lab will cover the statistical package, R, and data projects.

column5: Introduction To Data Science Tools And Models
column9: No indication of sustainability component.
column10: This course introduces key concepts in data management, preparation, and modeling and provides students with hands-on experience in performing these tasks using modern tools, including relational databases, pandas, and Spark. Models covered include k Nearest Neighbors, linear regression and gradient descent. For registration purposes, COMP 140 is a required prerequisite for this course. With instructor permission, students who have experience with the Python programming language may be allowed to special register for this course. Note that these students may be required to demonstrate proficiency with Python. Priority for this course is given to students enrolled in the data science minor. Other students may be permitted to enroll at the discretion of the instructor.

column9: No indication of sustainability component.
column10: This course is an introduction to concepts, methods, best practices, and theoretical foundations of machine learning. Topics covered include regression, classification, kernels, dimensionality reduction, clustering, decision trees, ensemble learning, regularization, learning theory, and neural networks.

column9: No indication of sustainability component.
column10: This course teaches fundamental data visualization skills to undergraduate students in the Data Science minor. Students will learn how to create data visualizations in Python or R, how to design effective visualizations that account for visual perception, and how to explain and present data to technical and non-technical audiences.

column9: This course discusses different types of ethics that deal with data and the practical applications of data in society -- which could be sustainability topics.
column10: An examination of the ethical implications and societal impacts of choices made by data science professionals. The course will provide practical guidance on evaluating ethical concerns, identifying the potential for harm, and applying best practices to protect privacy, design responsible algorithms, and increase the societal benefit of data science research.

column5: Applied Machine Learning And Data Science Projects
column9: Applied Machine Learning projects could deal with sustainability topics.
column10: In this project-based course, student teams will complete semester-long data science research or analysis projects selected from a variety of disciplines and industries. Students will also learn best practices in data science.

column5: Applied Machine Learning And Data Science Projects
column9: Applied Machine Learning projects could deal with sustainability topics.
column10: In this project-based course, student teams will complete semester-long data science research or analysis projects selected from a variety of disciplines and industries. Students will also learn best practices in data science.

column9: Focused on fundamentals, not their applications to sus challenges
column10: Introduction to the basic concepts of microeconomics and macroeconomics. Microeconomics component includes analysis of supply and demand, consumer and producer behavior, and competitive and noncompetitive market equilibria, with applications to current policy issues. Macroeconomics component provides an overview of the determination of national output, employment, interest rates, and inflation, and analyzes monetary fiscal policies and international trade.

column9: Focused on fundamentals, not their applications to sus challenges
column10: Intermediate level analysis of theories of household behavior, including demand for consumer goods, labor supply, and savings/investment decisions, and producer behavior including the supply of output and demands for labor, capital and other production inputs. Emphasizes individual and interactive decision making under resource constraints and discusses equilibria in competitive markets.

column9: Focus on fundamentals of law/economics rather than the applications of this field to sus challenges
column10: Exploration of the law using economic tools based on microeconomic theory. Focuses on legal issues most applicable to business.

column9: Although it could potentially draw from sustainability-related case studies, there is no notable focus on sustainability that would justify inclusion.
